reviews.review_title: Amazing experience if you know what you are getting into.
reviews.content: First, I think it should be a fair warning that this show is for mature audience. It has lots of violence and swearing. If you are uncertain, watch the 1st episode and see if that's your cup of tea.I found the show very entertaining on multiple levels. It has great story, humor, live and strong characters and excellent voice acting. Maybe that's because the main actors are actually voicing their own characters that they played on the 1st season of Critical Role. They created the characters so they know them inside out.I found the story to be progressing too fast. Maybe I am used to the Critical Role show and watching them trying to decide what to do for hours. In the show, all happens within minutes.The story and atmosphere are also both very dark so far. A lot darker than I had anticipated. I was expecting some parts of the show to be like that but I also expected to see some of the beautiful places of Tal'Dorei. So far, no dice (pun intended). I am hoping they will balance things out in the future.Nonetheless, can't wait for the next episodes.

I've always felt D&D would make great watching but until now haven't seen anything that captures the magic of role play. This show is the best version of that availabile and it's definitely less dungeoning and dragoning it captures the complexity of storytelling and character well. I actually think the episodes are too short.
I don't know what Critical Role is and I never heard of Vox Machina before finding this on Amazon but it was really excellent, funny, and intriguing. Fans of fantasy will be happy.
.. and that's because only 9 were available at the time.IThis show is fun, grim, epic and very worth watching if you like fantasy / dark fantasy, a true blast!

reviews.review_title: Review from a Non D&D fan
reviews.content: First I have to appreciate the awesome voice acting, back and forth between characters and beautiful animation. Guess thats why the hype was so great around this show. For non D&D fans like me I would say this show is good for binge watching it you are very much into high fantasy. Some negatives in my opinion rushed lore and relentless adult humor which became a annoyance after some time.

reviews.review_title: Better than expected, for adults only though
reviews.content: I had expected an anime style production but it is rather better.Very much adult orientated in both depiction and course language and it would also appeal to younger audiences if they produced a version suitable for them.

This plus Arcane are 2 of the best shows out there. Great writing, the animation fits perfectly and just enough humor to be present but not forced. Takes me back to my days of staying up till 3am drinking mountain dew and throwing dice.

Definitely recommended. Funny, well written and voice acted. Great show for any fans of D&D or fantasy adventure!My wife hates anything that's "fantasy land bullstuff", but she thought this show was pretty good and wants to watch it with me.I hope they keep making them!

Wow. What fun! Great writing, looks awesome, sounds amazing (the voices, sound effects, music, everything) and the story is fantastic. I won't spoil the end of ep 6, but what a perfect springboard for next season. I just can't say how much I like this and now the only problem will be waiting for another season. I hope it will have more than six episodes. Well done!

reviews.review_title: Vox Machina is a dirty, vulgar, raunchy, violent, bloody MASTERPIECE!
reviews.content: As a fan of Fantasy media AND D&D, I live for content revolving 'round either column and Critical Role's content is no exception to this. At the moment, I'm only on Episode 3 of the first campaign but the reason I'm not in deeper is because...well, the series is hours long and I can't be at my computer all that time.Regardless, I am happy that I don't have to be 100% familiar with the series' lore to know what's what. At least I know who the main good guys are, who the cast is and when the fun begins. I am so happy that the fans helped make this possible through the Kickstarter all those years ago.I only hope we'll get more from this than just the two seasons Amazon ordered.(Side Note: I also wish for the day Fantasy High from Dimension20 and CollegeHumor might be able to follow in CR's footsteps and get their own animated show, even if it is just online)

I was kind of surprised you can make adult fantasy series. Like aren't these for kids. Now that I see it this seems more rela than kiddish fantasy shows. Has good storyline. Has character building. The animation is awesome. The theme song is really nice. Got elements of humour in it. There are obviously elements to relate to here and there despite being fantasy. You really tear up on few scenes since they are so powerful. You can connect to the characters. This is one of the best series I have ever watched. This never feels kiddish at all. Well, one due to swearing, seems natural. It is exactly how adults would react if such situations arise and they have such powers.They won't just go and sacrifice their lives.If you are thinking I am fake praising just watch few episodes. You will get what I am saying.

I have been watching anime and cartoons for over 20 years. This is everything it should be. Great story, animation, funny antics, brilliant writing, and perfect voice actors to go along with it. Cannot say any more than what a brilliant series and also not to mention critical role is also spot-on. Old school DND and anime fan. Glad to see this is finally taking over.
Even if you're not a fan of Critical Role, you can absolutely still enjoy this show. It's fun, bawdy, wonderful, and right up your alley. Sit back and enjoy the fantastic characters of Vox Machina!

reviews.review_title: It's extremely good, wanted more Invincible, I got it.
reviews.content: Another great show by Amazon that has instantly filled my interest in watching more stuff like Invincible. I got the impression that it was like it, and it beautifully meets my expectations, and exceeds them.The dialogue is super funny, even though it may get too overly crude, but the legendary voice actors such Liam O'Brian of Gaara and Vincent Law, Gwen Tennyson's Ashley Johnson, and others including Khary Payton (Cyborg, Ezekiel, Aqualad) are making these characters sooo sassy and fun!I am loving it Soo far, and I hope for Vax and Keyleth romance!

reviews.review_title: Awesome fantasy action with great characters! :-)
reviews.content: Nice clean modern anime-style animation that looks great, especially in action! :-) Quirky, irreverent humor with an interesting cast of fantasy characters that are very different from each other, but still have a strong team bond! :-) A little like The Last Airbender / Korra dynamic, just way more adult! :-)

The first half of the show felt so rushed. The pacing was awful, the development was iffy, and I was a little sad. But the second half was incredible. I'm not just saying that as a fan of Critical Role. I'm saying that as a fan of fantasy and animation. The last half was amazing television. The fights were amazing, the animation top tier, the story perfect. Can't wait to see more.

I guess I was expecting more, given the good reviews.The animation is fantastic and the voice acting is good, but those are the only major positives I can think of.The story is just "okay". It's a bit rushed and force and we don't get much time to care about any of the characters or process what's going on.Character development is bad for almost all the characters. Vax and Keyleth go from never talking to one another to instantly being in love. It comes out of nowhere and has no time to grow at all. The only character who has half decent development is Percy. Everyone else is a bore. Pike is another one who comes out of left field. Her development happens way too quickly and we never get a chance to know her first.The humor is mostly terrible. I don't mind potty jokes or cussing at all. I LOVE South Park, and that's a show that does crude humor right. But it seems like Vox Machina's creators think that saying the F word randomly = funny, and that *any* sexual reference = funny. 90% of the time the jokes are just forced and lame. Cussing for the sake of cussing isn't funny, it's just bad writing.Overall I finished this, so it wasn't awful, but I was never pulled into it at any point.

Hello, i'm a critter.... just wanna get that out of the way hahawe did it, we did it, we did it, WE DID IT!!!!The first thing i wanna go over is how accurate this show already is to the arc's they are doing in the show! The first two episodes are a pre-stream arc that we've only heard about, and now we finally get to see it. This arc gives Vax and the other members their first lesson which is... no matter who you are, ALWAYS do the right thing. It saves livesthe ending of the second episode introduces one of, if not, my favorite arc of campaign 1 in introducing the Briarwoods. Here, i love that matt is voicing Sylas, it was the only way to do it!Overall i think the voice acting is fantastic, and there is nothing to complain about because nobody knows these characters as well as the voice actors. They played them for years before creating this show!WARNING: this show is more than rated R and has soooooooooo many adult themes and actions as in language (F words mostly), violence and gore, and nudity (as of right now, a short oral sex scene in the first episode that lasts about 15 seconds. Boobs, buttocks, and a slight glimpse at a man's testicles is seen)...this is exactly what i wanted (minus the sex and nudity)

Certainly falls victim of the usual adult animation shows. Where characters are constantly being loud and obnoxious. Constantly swearing to a point where it becomes unnatrual. Apart from that, it does have it's charms. Although this premise has been done before, and has been done better. All in all, not bad, but also not much to write home about.6/10: ok but meh.

reviews.review_title: Satisfying yet too fast at times
reviews.content: Great characters, decent storyline, but the dialogues are to Basic at times and everything seems a bit rushed and easy, mostly relationships.The plot moved forward at nice pacez but every character building is neglected in favor of unnecessary action.

reviews.review_title: We are in the golden era of fantasy animation
reviews.content: This show to me is the pure distillation of what good fantasy is supposed to be. Sexy, rowdy, and evoking genuine investment in the characters through their onscreen cameraderie, banter and slowly unfolding respective backstories. Absolutely gorgeously animated, easily the top tier of current Western fare, stunningly choreographed and unsurprisingly voiced to absolute pergection, this show represents the true joy of imagination and escapism while roleplaying. It might be the one small hurdle to a mainstream public as some beats might not always feel the most natural, but it doubles the enjoyment for those of us who are familiar with these voices and how the game works with the layer of meta in which it blankets the show.I can't imagine how the immense crowd of backers must feel, watching their dream come to life and seeing that every single cent was well-spent. I hope this opens the door for more grassroots animation projects.Right now I have the difficult balancing act of ravenously waiting for the next batch of episodes while also not wanting the show to ever get closer to an endpoint. Here's hoping its success will ensure many more seasons to come.

reviews.review_title: I'm being Critical, that's my Role
reviews.content:
Fun D&D cartoon for adults. I'm a casual viewer of CR so I know the characters and Voice actors but it doesn't really matter if you don't. It's loud and brash with lots of swearing and some sex stuff...(Pearl clutchers beware lol)
It is let down by cheap, 'Saturday morning cartoon' animation tbh which can be rather clunky but it's fun and silly so it's not the end of the world. It's certainly not a 10, they are just CR Stan scores. A solid 7 is fare I think.

This is a good gory adult comedy. Good to just kick back, relax and watch. I highly recommend it! I hope there will be another season!These characters are hilarious but down to earth. The gore is beautifully done. The character's could use a little more lines to make it seem more than just good one liners but that's just my opinion. I'm not one for continual seasons to a descent show but I think this has potential to be some good relaxing fun.

This show will likely be one of those that people will either love or hate. There will be very few reviews in between. It has that baseline crude humour which has made Rick and Morty a hit and given it a cult following.The Legend of Vox Machina ('Vox Machina') provides more of that same crude humour. There aren't any high brow, think about it for a minute before it becomes funny, jokes in here. They smack you in the face like a full diaper, pick it back up and hit you again with it.The storey of Vox Machina centres around a band of misfit adventurers that have very little going for them, who are drafted to kill a monster destroying the kingdom/realm. Are they up to the task? Probably not! However, they give it their best, and... Yeah, I'm not going to spoil it for you.You're going to have to watch the show for that. Sorry.I quite liked the animation of Vox Machina, which isn't as over the top when compared to most Japanese Anime, and isn't crude like a lot of animation done in the past 10-15 years. It's high quality, well coloured and varied.The voice acting is very good. I don't know many of the actors here, but you can tell they're getting into their characters, trying to make you believe in the story, the world and their animated lives.On a final note, Amazon have only dropped 3 episodes so far. Hopefully the show retains the current level of humour, animation and voice quality and the story progresses nicely. I'm looking forward to more.If you're one of those people who is a little high strung, is easily offended and gets annoyed when someone farts in your general direction. Don't watch this. You're not going to enjoy it. If you like Rick and Morty, The Boys or Invincible, then this is likely to be something you'll enjoy as well.

First: I am an huge critter from Germany! Normally i dont watch animated series, but with Arcane and OF COURSE The Legend of Vox Machina i am making some exceptions!IF there would be no Arcane, i would give this show an 10/10, but even as a fan i have to be realistic and an 9/10 is still STELLAR!The voiceacting is of course the best in the business, the animations are great and i know most of the story, so i know HOW AWESOME it will be.Especially the character arcs will be one of many reasons to love this show for fantasy and animated series fans.This show is what DND needed, forget these Boll movies or something like that, this is the new milestone for fantasy series with an classical DND setting. Violence, blood, dirty jokes, swear words and not holding back with "adult stuff"! This is not for kids and that is exactly what i wanted!I hope a lot of people outside this bubble give it a shot, it is really an really good series and the idea behind all of this are people that dont have profit in their mind, they really CARE and LOVE DND and the story/characters they have created over the years! Enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Tries too hard to be funny
reviews.content: Tries too hard to be funny, but the jokes are written by a 15-year-old high school boy. The characters are all eh. If you're really a fan of fantasy, you might endure it just to see the plot happen though.
Plenty of Debbie downers in the user reviews still, but like many others I completey disagree that this isn't a good show. Especially with what's been available lately.

Really good series but it didn't seem as shocking to me as it was presented to me. It is a great mix of sad, funny, epic and irreverent scenes. It is not so strange when you think that this series was born from a game of DnD. Too bad for some monsters made with bad CGI.

I find IMDb so strange now days. It's often either 10/10 or 2/10 reviews, very little in between - hence why I felt I had to leave a review!I know nothing about the source material, but overall this a fun, magical, animated journey that definitely doesn't take itself too seriously.The plot is ok, the animation is good with some really satisfying gore filled moments (although occasionally let's itself down particularly some of the dragon scenes) the script constantly filled with very crude jokes, which I like! All of the characters are actually pretty great, potentially even the strongest aspect of the show.Ultimately, it's Definitely worth a watch, but it's not going to blow you away.

The first few episodes are a bit slow and uneven but the series really gets going once the Briarwoods arc begins. It gets progressively better with each episode.Love all the Easter eggs. The series definitely delivers on the fan service.

reviews.review_title: Initial Impression: Somehow Already Way Over-rated
reviews.content: Come on this show is average quality plot and dialogue. If audiences didnt know who was behind making it, it wouldn't be successful at all. This is a prime example of reception based on "what it is" and not on "how good it is". The show has good animation and a great concept but the plot, characters, and dialogue are all really lacking. I was super excited for this show and have been dissappointed. So much missed potential. The show is average. In reality its not doing anything more than the average anime or animated action/comedy. People are giving the show top tier ratings because it comes from a source they really like. So much source bias in movies and tv shows.
It's really fantastic writing, good animation and everything else is also amazing. Ofcourse this show deserves 10 stars!! I'm so excited for the next new episode :)

reviews.review_title: Exactly what I had hoped for
reviews.content:
With a cast of perfect voice actors, all characters act and behave exactly like I expected from the show.Animation is great (though I admit, not on par with Arcane)The humor is great, and the story is interesting.Spoilers:
The story is pretty rushed. We are talking about 20 hours on game sessions compressed into 1½ hour for the first 3 episodes. But it doesn't waste any of the time it does have.The fight scenes are great, but when Grog says: "I...would like...to RAGE!!!" it actually brought a tear to my eye. The end fight in episode 2 actually feels appropriately epic.

reviews.review_title: Exactly how we wanted them to do this.
reviews.content: Ok, get past episode 1.Its a somewhat rocky start but once episode 2 hits its great, and episode 3 is fantastic. I can only feel that it's going to get better and better because of the potential of this story.Great writing utilizing its source material in an exciting way while it's still condensing hours of story.The voice acting, of course, is top notch. The collected cast, including (almost) all of the original performers, and an incredible brought in supportive cast.The Animation's good, I love the renderings of these characters.But all in all, they're nailing the original chaotic energy, and the deep drama that the initial game had.Fantastic stuff.
Last time I had such vibe from cartoon when saw Castlevania .It's pretty well written show , which has unique characters ,astonishing plot and R-rated content.

I deliberately avoided Vox Machina content for the pupose of being able to watch the animated series with fresh unbiased eyes, and I am enjoying EVERYTHING so far!You can tell that the voiceactors knows their characters intimately and put their heart and soul into their performance. If you have played Dungeons & Dragons (like me) you will have tons of fun recognizing spells, actions, monsters, and how unhinged the collective stotytelling can get, as well as how dramatic and emotional it suddenly can turn. The characters are flawed but compelling, which makes me look forward to how they are going to evolve together. They have distinct personalities that mesh well with each other and cause for fun interactions, which is only emphasized by the cast being close friends in real life.It has definitely earned it's R-rating (so be mindful if that is a turn-off for you!) but for me it's delightfully vulgar because it really capture the spirit of roleplaying at a table with close friends in a high fantasy setting. This is by the word's fullest meaning a LABOUR OF LOVE, and I'm so happy to watch it all come to life. I will absolutely follow this story to the end.

reviews.review_title: A good show with an admittedly rough start
reviews.content: The idea of a "Dungeons and Dragons" series sounded interesting, but I was skeptical after seeing the more raunchy tone this show had adopted. At first this show had little appeal, relying heavily on the adult humor to entertain and containing little depth. However, after the first few episodes, the show improves greatly and is able to become more serious without overly relying on bad jokes. It's not a perfect show by any means, but with some character work and an excellent finale, "The Legend of Vox Machina" proves itself to be worthwhile show, despite some of its rough patches. A good watch if it's what you are into.
The first episode isn't exactly GREAT, but episodes 2 and 3 have been solid gold and this is from somebody who has never watched Critical Role. It's a great show and I can't wait for more.

Anyone looking for a well written and brilliantly voice acted animation are in for a fun ride. This captures the fun of friends at the table playing D&D with the joy of watching an adult animation that is not worried about coloring in the lines of the cultural norm. Sit back, poor a bourbon and enjoy the show it is worth it.

reviews.review_title: Season 2 is a big improvement. S1(7.8) S2(8.9)
reviews.content: As someone who read the manga (pushes glasses up nose), I was a little disappointed with how the characters (mostly Scanlan) were portrayed in the first season. They weren't bad (except Scanlan), but they didn't feel like real characters. The source material feels like a podcast (it is) with real people who talk and have conversation. I thought the 7 main characters were were more caricatures of the people they were based on.Season 2 fixes that and is great. The plot slows down and has arcs for all of them to shine. The action is just as good (with better CGI) and there's more of it. I thought they were going to squeeze this part of the story into one season but it appears to be taking up at least half of the next season. I thought they were going to cut an arc that Scanlan went through but they executed on it well added depth to him.Anyway Season 2 is like Season 1 with deeper characters.

I have only watched a little of critical role, but have played a lot of d&d throughout the years.Didn't know what to expect of this show, but after watching 2 episodes, I am quite pleasently suprised! Great characters and interaction between them, the voice acting is really on point, the animations are good (not great, but good!), the story is captivating, and also a healthy mix of humor and gore.Very much looking forward to the progression of the series! Well done!

reviews.review_title: If you are/were ever a roleplayer, you get it. If not, YMMV
reviews.content: Within the ranks of TTRPGers there are two camps, usually. Those, like me and I suspect the majority of the playerbase, who want to have fun and not take things too seriously. Then there are those who seek to turn every session into The Lord of the Rings.Some of the best times I ever had as a TTRPGer were when my friends and I just goofed around and had fun in game. Vox Machina screams of people doing just that, much as the Critical Role campaign it comes from.Most of the negative comments seem to be from what I'll politely refer to as "The Puritanical Brigade" outraged by the language and humour and the notion that there might be sex in an animated show.It was never marketed as anything other than an adult-oriented show. The trailers did not shy away from showing either language, humour or gore. Yet it seems to come as a complete surprise to some people that these things are present throughout each episode.Now, in the past I have decried crass humour and the like. But that was in shows that were never meant to contain them in the first place, like the awful Shannara Chronicles for example. Vox Machina, by contrast, never offered the "Lord of the Rings" as the model to judge it on. It is, and always was, a bunch of friends having fun playing a role-playing game, along with all the banter, interactions and humour that come with that territory.As for the show as a show? Well the animation feels a little rough in places, but it has a style that reminds of the 80's quite strongly. It is perfectly fine, though I'd be happier if they added a few more frames here and there when the action heats up.It is impossible to fault the voice acting either, since the original voice actors from Critical Role are reprising their roles here. If they don't know how their own characters should be, then who would?Story-wise it's a familiarly simple TTRPG, session-based affair with no real surprises as to who is good and who is evil. It's not anything ground-breaking, but it is serviceable and let's be honest... you're watching more for the characters than the plot.Overall, I'm finding it fun and entertaining, much like those TTRPG sessions of old. Now all I need to do is get a T-shirt with "I played D&D before it was cool" on it and I'll be set!SUMMARY: Harmless roleplaying fun aimed at grown-ass adults, not ones who use the term "potty-mouth" to talk about language. Gamers will get more mileage out of it, especially if they, like me, have fond memories of their own gaming exploits around a table.

reviews.review_title: Has so much potential, very excited
reviews.content: Personally I feel that the first two episodes felt a bit rushed in terms of story progression and at times the dialogue felt a bit strange. Now the negatives are over, the animation is fantastic, the story is compelling and episode 3!!! Wow episode 3 was amazing, Silas Briarwood felt menacing and was set up amazingly, Delilah was also great and am looking forward to seeing more about their story and how it ties in with the Whispering One. I am really looking forward to the rest of this series and I think it's going to be amazing.

(Episodes 1-12) Perhaps in an attempt to brace us for the show's more easy-going but graphic style, Vox Machina is initially laden with immature depictions of random violence and humor. This persists throughout much of the show, especially anytime Scanlan is in scene. But past that we are given glimpses of real backstory with potential for compelling narrative, notably where Pike and Percy are concerned, and action scenes that shape up to be quite nice during serious moments. In addition, the animations on backgrounds and the opening are worthy of attention for their beauty. For those of us who have no knowledge of Critical Role especially, It's still unlikely to become a "masterpiece" but, at the very least, it offers a fun and entertaining ride.

This could have been a great tv series.Unfortunately, I think it is quite uncertain about the targeted audience.There's clearly gory and bloody stuff that makes it not for kids, but at the same time, the plots and dialogs seem to have been written by a 10 years old game master....
Also, the comedy bites are predictable, and absolutely awful (as a 10 yo joke...) and they should definitely improve it or else, get rid of any funny stuff for a more mature and darker ambiance.All, in all, as a former Tabletop rpg player and game master, I was expecting so much from it... Eventually, this comes up as an average show that is still enjoyable but quite frustating at the same time.Lodoss war was better at its time.

I play RPGs and have watched some Critical Role videos before watching this.I really didn't like what I saw in the first few episodes. But I think with time they've started to learn what the sweet spot is when transforming what happened at the table to the screen.The first few episodes I would probably rate as 6/10. The pacing was bad, and scenes of unnecessary gore, nudity and bad jokes were too frequent and because of that more annoying than meaningful.It's just an entirely different thing if someone comes up with a bad joke at the table once per 3-hour session, then it is when the time is compressed for the show, and you get 5 of them per 20-minute episode.If the future seasons of the show will be more like the second half of the first season, I will be very happy.

reviews.review_title: It's rough, but not bad.. Unless you start thinking about it.
reviews.content: Overall i enjoyed the fantasy world, adult-themed jokes, blood and all the stuff you'd rather avoid showing to kids. It felt fresh.. and gory. This review gonna have spoilers.Introduction to the world was pretty good. Tbh I got baited by the shows first scene aka Suicide Squad, where we follow 'wrong' team only to see their demise. Then we meet our "correct" team. Gotta say in the bar scene i did chuckle more than once, which is quite amazing achievement for a show.In all honesty I have hard time coming up with saying the good stuff. There are plenty of things there that i liked, but.. Lemme just focus on key aspects that didn't work all that much for me.Show tries to tell us that Dragons are capital B - BIG problem. It's the stuff you need an army to beat. Okay. Makes sense. In D'n'D fighting a Dragon is the finale of an adventure. In Vox machina... Killing a Dragon, Apex Predator, The Magical being with a status "legendary badass, do not touch" is used as an introduction to our teams teamwork. I liked how they killed the dragon.. But you simply DO NOT do that. It really wrecks with power levels. It's like Harry Potter beating Voldemort in the first book, or Luke killing his Vader and Imperator right at the start of his jedi adventure. Again, I liked HOW they killed the big winged lizard, but it's poor choice for the story.My second problem is kind of continuation of the first: Power levels. The magic powers in this world are really wonky so to speak. The biggest offenders here are Pike and Keyleth. Key' is the inexperienced adventurer/successor to elf throne (or something). And her power is inconsistent as hell. Sometimes her spells hardly do anything, while other times she's literally a walking nuke of a mage fueled by the shounen power of "because i really want to". It's difficult to invest in story when few spells do nothing, only to the final one making up for it by 10000x cause 'reasons'. Pike on the other hand is a paladin of sorts. Her powers also resemble drunked seismograph. They work.. Untill show decides she has faith issues... Then she's out of the team for a while only to return as a demigod spewing enough power as if she's some kind of magical dynamo of invinite power. She teleports as astral projection to different country, then she can fly, mass-enchant, mass heal, shoot lazor beams, throw light-weapons left, right and middle. And even with all that power she's only usefull untill director says "okay, you can stop now" and her power tap is turned off. And it's not that she loses her power. Her power simply stop being a threat. What a stellar script... If it was written by a highschooler. If you think this is cool and totally good writing, then you are the type of person that gets amazed by toothpaste advertisments and you shouldn't grade anything, cause it's beyond your mental capacity.Another thing is the world itself. It's a high fantasy world. You've got loads of races. Alot of magic and magical beings and.. Both the king and the "army" is as mundane as my socks. If you don't see the problem.. Imagine Fort Knoxx (a big safe full of gold in Kentucky) having its locks made out of.. lets be generous and say: paper. Oh "but what about thieves" you say? See, you know that thieves exist and therefore you know you need proper defenses and mechanisms to keep the gold safe. In the world of Vox Machina king has zero protections whatsoever. The guy was literally enchanted/hypnotized on a banquet WHILE EVERYONE WAS WATCHING. There should be at least 50 alarms, or 10 mage-guards turbo-vibrating getting ready to fight. But there's nothing. The army in this world is also a prop. Only to show if something is scary by showing how quickly it minces the "army" in gory scenes. They hold zero value on their own. Hack writing.Overall: kingdowm is a joke. Army is a joke. Sovereign isn't even a quest-giver but a teritary side-mention of least importance AKA he's pure incompetence in a form of a joke. The world is simply fake. And................ I understand why. It's all about Vox Machina adventures.. But if that's the case director should have simply removed the uneccessary bits. Remove all the unimportant things like: kingdom, king, army, royal council (which is also a bad joke). We don't need to see that. Use it only if you have a goal in mind. If it doesn't add half a sh to the world, then don't bother, cause you'll constrict yourself later. Just fcus on the team and adventure. Well.. It's too late for that now.My final of the "this world makes no bloody sense" problem is how nonsensical the main plot is. Long story short: one of VM members is Percy. His whole family of high-nobles has been slaughtered. Stuff like that doesn't get hushed up. Especially not when those nobles were ruling a pretty big city. Director did try to cover it with some excuse, but that was so god awful I can;t even put it into words. If we were to go by real world example: imagine country.. Lets go with USA.. where first thing you, as a prisident, learn that whole council and mayor of... New York kinda got bored and quit their job, gave it away to some random hobo. You don't get any info beyond that. Soon after the whole city closes its borders and you no longer receive any informations from it. As a president, you'd send whole damn ARMY to check what the f is going on... But out incompetent director using the power of a script made an excuse that it's fine cause we tried to send few scouts and it failed tee-hee.This whole plot would have shattered in thousand pieces if on the banquet Percy said out loud who he is and what has happend to his family and by whom, which should have caused a cascade of reactions and actions. But that is.. if the world was actually well written.Ok, so this ends up my list of "BIG BADs". The "small bads".. I'd say I have only 1. The character of Grog. I don't have anything against Drax ripoffs. But this one was just.. His dialogue and "i am very simple barbarian" way of talking was mishandled. Not to mention the voice actor just doesn't fit the person in my opinion. But VA voice is the smallest problem here. Overall Grogs way of talking was fake as hell and it felt like someone scraping a knife on the plate whenever there was some banter.On the "so good I need to mention it" list we have Voice Actors of Vex and Vax. Amazing job. They are pros. And whatever they get paid I can say one thing: it definitely was not enough. Then we have whole character of Scanlan. Also quite interesting. Rest kinda existed and thats the best i can say about them. Sorry.---Should you watch it? It's a decent show. I liked it and i dont regret spending around 3 hours on it. If you can tune out logic it gets alot better. Although saying "after lobotomy this show gets really good!" is a very low crap-bar. Director is a newbie at his job and it shows. And if he's not a newbie, but a veteran... Then I don't think he should be anywhere near directors seat.If you like gore, adult jokes (of varying heights.. and lows) with decent'ish-at-best western animation.. Go ahead and watch it :)

reviews.review_title: Story has potential, dialogue holds it back.
reviews.content: I am not someone who is familar with Crtical Role but have taken apart of D&D campaigns at times and watched D&D shows/podcasts.Legend of Vox Machina opens with 3 episodes that right away can help you decide if the show is for you or not. The animation and fantasy story are pretty well done but the dialogue between characters is quite poor. I can see in a live environment the lewd jokes being made so often landing well, but in a show envirornment it misses a lot more than it hits and almost caused me go turn it off a few times.The show isn't a top quality project, but it isn't trying to be. Its a passable time killer.

reviews.review_title: The few that are complaining please sit down
reviews.content: The people complaining about swearing and violence are either kidding themselves, have never watched anything r rated, never watched Invincible, or just want to seem cool and special compared to everyone else. For all of you that think any of the above, please sit down, this show isn't for you. If however, you want great animation, stellar voice acting, a really intriguing story that both adheres to and subverts standard fantasy tropes then welcom new critter and enjoy the fun, dark, irreverent ride.

I love traditional hand drawn animation (as opposed to CGI, which in general I hate). This show has some of the most beautiful, dynamic animation I've seen. It's amazing. Okay, its not on a par with Ghost In The Shell 1 and 2 or Studio Ghibli, but what is. It's still incredible. The opening credits sequence is great, and it really sets the tone. If you like very raunchy humour, which I do, there are some laughs in this show. If not, it might not be for you. The story is varied and interesting, and there are some great and memorable villains in here. I think this would make an excellent video game, preferably 2D action, or even a 2D side scrolling beat em up, where you get to choose from, or switch between the seven heroes. The cast of villains would make for great end of level bosses. While on the subject of the heroes, they are varied, and every one is memorable. The episodes are about 25 minutes long, which is a perfect length in my opinion, and there are 10 of them, so not too much to get through. If you like animation and raunchy adult humour, coupled with an adventure, check it out. It's quite a lot better than the massively overrated Castlevania, and as an added bonus, it's not woke, at all. Highly recommended, for the right audience.

This is animation done right. Excellent character design and development with just enough backstory given to each of the main protagonists. Gorgeous backgrounds and color schematics used throughout the show, high level of detail and that matches the world building perfectly wherever the scenes head. Absolutely masterfully crafted. Hilarious dialogue that keeps things light but can turn on the drama when needed. It was hard to imagine the second season being better than the first but I was thrilled to see it was indeed better. The only problem I have with this show is that each season is to damn short! Really hope we get a season 3 to wrap up the nail biter ending from season 2!

Season 2 was more enjoyable - I really want to see season 3. Well done to the creators.This was done last year:
I realised that I hadn't reviewed this until now, when you compare it to anime, its quite lame but when compared to animation(by the way a big difference from anime) its great fun and love the development between the characters, but if you are looking for a deep storyline and meaningful interaction it is shallow. Don't get me wrong they do try.But if you want a night of vegetating and nothing too serious. This is it.The accents can be annoying. But honestly I had to give it a 8 as I do hope to see more of it. Just because of the short guy who is hilarious and probably the best thing in it.

A lot of these fools who keep giving it a low rating have no idea how much work and time it took to make, not only the show, but also the source material. Countless hours upon hours of people making these grand stories and characters. To see it come to life in animation is glorious!I swear, most of the people giving low reviews would look at the Mona Lisa and say "so what? What's the big deal? If it wasnt made by a famous guy then no one would like it." Without any idea of the effort that went into such a task.Please ignore them. Try the show. If it's not your cup of tea, then luckily there's lots of other stuff to watch.Thank you for reading.

So it's inspired by D&D, I never played but I know enough from nerd culture to understand the concept and amazing job on the artwork and character design.I'm finding it difficult to find reasons to like these characters, from the get-go you gave us this illusion of strong characters, from the way that they're designed and the way they behaved. But the more I watch, there's no substance. Some characters are extremely stereotypical, others are so boring you start to wonder why are they main characters.A lot of the writing makes me think there is something that I'm missing or that I don't understand. Even when they were attacked where some of them seemed like they died, I did not care, I was not rooting for them or against them, just watching in boredom and indifference, so I blame the writing more than anything.What kind of writing is this! Two slit throats one after the other, two spitting one after the other, and so many moments like that, where it loses its effect because of repetition of the same concept in the same episode or even sometimes in the next episodeAnd it's not that the characters are not likable, they are "Misfits". I love the concept of Misfits, but these are boring one dimensional misfits.

reviews.review_title: Avatar and Pulp Fiction had a Baby
reviews.content: Complaints of childish humor and filthy language are spot on. Nudity is done in whatever the opposite of tasteful is.I play D&D occasionally.I've never heard of the pod cast before this.The show is brilliant entertainment in the same mode as Archer. It goes out of its way to be offensive.If you want to laugh out loud for 20 minutes and walk away having forgotten the real world for a bit. It's worth a watch.

"The Legend of Vox Machina" (S01, 12 eps, 1/2hr, Amazon) is a slickly produced animated series that reminds one of "Castlevania", however, though the show centers on teen characters I think the story is really kiddie-oriented, it's a real letdown. It's full of stereotypes, clichés, and it's predictable - just the right mix of elements for your pre-teen. I really wanted to like this, especially since Covid has brought us so much stinking messes of films and series, but this didn't break through for me, just more of the same type of wasted effort as so many others.

reviews.review_title: The heroes of Vox Machina... and a walking dick joke.
reviews.content: I REALLY want to like this show, and a lot of it is really good, but after 9 episodes I absolutely cannot stand Scanlan and think the character drags down the entire production.In the original streamed Campaign he has his share of sex jokes, innuendo and low brow humor, but ultimately the character is much more nuanced than that and there's actual depth and humanity to him.In this adaptation he's a walking dick joke with a sprinkle of toilet humor and that's literally it. It's a shame because other characters, particularly Pike, Percy and Keyleth so far, have really been given depth and development that adds to what they were in the OG campaign and there's some really moving scenes. Pike's development and story has been absolutely masterful and could not be more antithetical to the completely one dimensional Scanlan of this series.The animation itself is incredible, as are the rest of the cast, full time members and guests. Certainly there is plenty of crude humor in the live streams, but in the scope of the entire campaigns so far, it's not the unending steam that the animated series has chosen to embrace so fully., and some of it is funny and it has its place, but too much feels forced here.The OG characters are all incredible as are the folks voicing them and they are all ridiculously talented and capable of creating tension, drama, tender moments and laughs without having to go for the low hanging fruit/base humor for every single laugh.I hope Scanlan evolves into more in future seasons, but honestly this just really makes me want a Mighty Nein adaptation so much more instead.

I will preface this review by saying I do not watch any of critical role's podcasts but still managed to finish and enjoy this series. However, there is no way this show deserves a 9 or 10, maybe if you are a long time cr fan and you've already watched this adventure in their podcast form, you were able to get more nuances as to the characters relationships and find little easter eggs in the show that made you go "YAY! There's the thing that i know from the podcast!" But, for everyone else, there are certain dialogues and scenes that are unnecessary and thrown in there purely for fan service.However, all that being said the journey that the heroes take was very entertaining and kept me watching for all 12 episodes, but again gets ruined by the absolutely unsatisfying ending! I was really disappointed by how the villains were built up for like 9 episodes and then for them to have little or no impact at the end. Maybe season 2 will change all that, however, the way the villains died were so lame; and then immediately we were thrust into another conflict right at the end, it was so absurdly abrupt. This probably worked very well in the podcasts but it does not work here.Now, the show wasn't all terrible, i really enjoyed the middle part of the story, especially episodes 6-10, there were some great and tense moments there. And going into the final 2 episodes i had the show at a 7 or 7.5 even! So even though the ending was unsatisfying, i still would recommend this show to anyone who enjoys fantasy.My rating system is based on the scale where 5/10 is considered an average show, it's a show that's fine but doesn't do anything unique but is still enjoyable, so a 6/10 is above average for me, and that's what this show is to me, it is slightly above average.
For Last times told you how much say bad language such as.even kept saw a lot of Killed, Which has also characters. Well That is so pretty good and I hope we enjoy the new series!

Really a fantastic show. A perfect representation of the tabletop rpg experience. It very much kept the "feeling" of the Livestream the show is based on. Only the first three episodes are out now, but reviewers who were able to see the first six say it only gets better from here! Can't wait.

reviews.review_title: I can't recommend it highly enough - just breathtaking!
reviews.content: The terror was real -the stakes were made very clear within the first 5 minutes and only got scarier as time when on. The world is expansive, rich in detailed lore, and so wonderfully animated that the dragons inspire actual awe - as all beautiful and terrifying things do. The voicing acting is breathtaking - Groon will lull you to sleep while Thordak will scare you back out of bed. It's grim and funny and heart-wrenching in rapid succession. The characters' stories begin to unfold as their determination and desperation grow to new heights. I highly recommend to any adult who likes high fantasy with a little kink.

reviews.review_title: Best D&D show since Dungeons and Dragons cartoon from the 80's!
reviews.content: I am really enjoying watching this show! Hope it keeps up the entertainment. I wasn't too sure at first since there have been so many failed movie attempts but they really pulled off a good show. I suppose because they are actually D&D players too.

Not only is this show fun and entertaining to watch, but the writing is also fantastic! The story has so much depth to it, something that doesn't seem like it was overlooked because it's animated. You can tell this show was a labor of love and tremendous amounts of thought went into the creation. The show recommends 16+, but I would say that's a stretch. 18+ is more realistic. Highly recommend!
It's everything I wanted! I just want more. MORE! Please people at Amazon or whatever, throw money at this so we get even more seasons and maybe even another show for Campaign 2! THANK YOU CR!! <3.

reviews.review_title: Immature Adult Humour hurts the show
reviews.content: Overall not bad. Give it a 6 out of 10. Enough here to make me check out the next 3 episodes.Worst part of the show is the Humour. It seems to me as Adult Humour written by a 13 year old. I find it a bit cringy and of putting at times. Where the show works is when they have to get together to and do something. Looking out for each other as a team to help fight the enemy is where this show is strongest.

Do you like the TTRPG vibe and storytelling method? The distinctive way the protagonists are introduced and their backstories intertwine with the plot? The tropes and stereotypes of DnD, as well as this unshakable feeling characters have an OOC train of thought?Hate how Critical Role is bloated with the pretend rolling, too much TT and not enough RP?This is the show for you. No people sitting around a table, only their fantasy.Well animated, too.

reviews.review_title: A fun romp that doesn't take itself too serious
reviews.content: There are so many films and shows in this genre that take themselves way to seriously. This isn't one. From ball-tag to the back-and-forth quips that remind me of my brother and I, it keeps you entertained. That said, there is a rather serious quest involved and decent story telling. It hits the rocks a couple times and that halfling is a touch much from time to time, but the characters are well formed and consistent, the musical score adds to the story and ambiance (unlike Willow) and the balance between serious story telling and inane humor is well struck. I honestly can't wait for Season 2.
I love it!Intriguing plot with great characters that does not take themselves seriously at all, R rated humor and tons of fun.Fantasy world at its best.

The legend of vox machina is a truly amazing show and a must watch for anyone remotely interested in fantasy or even if you're not I recommend it! Great storytelling, great dialogue, wonderful characters and villains, great animation and action. What more could you want? There's depth to their heroes and villains. There's growth. There's comradery and conflict. Humor and darkness and violence and more! You get to know and like these characters and understand who they are. This show is an adaption of a D and D campaign by the very voice actors themselves but you dont need to have watched it or even play D and D to understand it or keep up or anything. It's an engaging show start to finish and you won't be disappointed!

I am currently re-watching the first season and I like it more the second time. Please don't change a thing. Keep the writers they are doing a wonderful job. I say that as there have been other good shows and they swap a writer and it goes south quick. It refreshing to watch a show that isn't WOKE. Unlike some of the other animated shows this one you can really get into. By that I mean you get into the story and before you realize it the episode it over, where as others (Dragon Prince) I am looking at the clock waiting for it to be done. Or the aweful Dragon Age Absolution which has a list of issues. Amazon you have a hit here, don't screw it up.

It has character, storyline, originality, light-heartedness, epic battles and climactic endings. This is just an amazing show.Another plus is that it's very rewatchable because of how intricate the storyline gets, and each character really has standalone qualities. Scandling (spelling?) could have his own spinoff series hands down. 👏

reviews.review_title: I was a casual watcher of Critical Role, so far, so good.
reviews.content: My son started me watching CR. I wouldn't normally have watched a bunch of guys playing D&D, but I recognized so many of the voice actors that I had to watch. I don't think I watched closely enough to know the story as well as my son does, so the story is fresh for me and I still get to enjoy Laura, Travis and Liam doing what they love. Lots of fun!

The story is nice, I like the adult profile that to my criteria give some realism to the fantasy. The parody in the very intro of the show is funny and screams: this is not yet another LOTR tale, and also warn you about the graphic nature of the story.By the way the story is at the end something you expect in a fantasy show, I mean is not bad is something you expect and likes in this kind of shows.The drawings and scenarios are outstanding and beautiful, the characters also looks so cool and some has original powers, however as I'm very used to anime, I found the animation little rude or rigid. Some action scenes are just impressive but some simple scenes like people walking remind me old bad cartoons from my youth.I general I like it but I was expecting better relationships between the characters.

The cast and crew of Critical Role poured there love into this series and while it is animation, its done well and passionately enough that long time fans as well as new comers to the genre can enjoy it alike.
It seems a Suicide Squad in a fantasy world. I couldn't really get interested in the characters, least of all Scalan, an annoying and arrogant brat who thinks everything is about sex.

I passed this over on Prime for months thinking it was just another crappy low budget DnD cash grab. Those never really work well outside of games. Wow was I wrong.Now mind you I am not saying this is a masterpiece. Not really. There is still a lot of tongue in cheek moments and shameless homage (aka copying) going on here. There is really nothing new in terms of character design, story or what have you but it was, simply put, very well made. Sometimes you dont need to invent something new. Sometime you just need to put it together well and thats what they did here.They glued DnD together, as varied and disjoint as it can be, and made it work. The major RPG classes were presented in a funny, campy way that made it more enjoyable than I thought it would be. Dialog was fun at times, action was good, we had dark humor here and there and though there were boring parts and constipated characters (clerics... lol), it just worked. Quick warning, this is not a show for kids. Im not going to be showing this to my 7 year old.Im looking forward to season 2.

reviews.review_title: Amazon was at it's prime wen dey cooked up this idea, from om 1 legend to another
reviews.content: Every moment was worth every episode of the show, words can't seem to find a fitting description for this cause it blew me off the planet, talk about character role playing voice and every element this was on a whole new level of entertainment.AMAZON you have my thoughts, you really did it.

Everyone marking 10 stars is blinded by the excitement of this series existing at all. Yes, it's a fun series with great dialog and well done animation. Yes, it's a unique series that will have an amazing place among other cartoons and possibly pave the way for more D&D content. But it's not perfect. Like all works made for a specific audience, it focuses on gaining views through fanservice rather than solid quality.Why does Vex seek information about dragons from a magic items dealer when she herself said she's an expert on them? To introduce Gilmore for no reason other than to make a cameo appearance, of course.Why does Uriel hire Vox Machina as the exclusive protectors of Emon after a single task they were lucky to complete? To set up the series without all the adventures in the original story to back it up.Why does Grog yell "I would like to rage" out loud? Because that was his player's catch phrase in the game of Critical Role. Think about how absurd of a battle cry that would be for an actual fighter in a fantasy universe to say in character. It's like Keyleth yelling "I would like to cast call lightning on the dragon!"I'm sure this show will be enjoyable for critters all the way through, myself included, but objectively people have to realize it's not a 10-star show. It's contrived for the fans who backed the Kickstarter and not for general audiences, and I guess we'll see if that's enough to keep it alive.

I've listened to critical role in the podcast format for years and was excited for this show. The first season was good, not mind blowing but a solid show and very enjoyable, but maybe a little forgettable and generic. Now maybe I feel that way because I already know what's going to happen and am familiar with the story. However season 2 is absolutely outstanding. Even though I already knew most of what was going to happen the way the material was presented and the beautiful way they animated each scene actually surprised me. Normally when something is left up to my imagination the actual final visualization pales in comparison, not this time. If your thinking about watching I highly recommend you stick around until season 2, I think you'll find it worth it.

I'll admit, it starts a little slow with the first episode, but by the third, DAMN!!! Sylas and Delilah Briarwood are cunning and beautifully designed, and I love them so far as villains!!! I also loved seeing a bit of Percival's backstory at the beginning of episode 3. It's truly amazing seeing all the love put into this show.Even with the 20 minute episodes, they manage to cram a good amount of plot, dialogue, and action into each episode. This show is stunning visually, and ofc with an amazing cast! I'm very exited to see what they have in store for this show!!!
So far this has been great. I love the show and the podcast. I may be a little bias because I know how much heart and soul has been put in this series. Can't wait for more!

I have never ever heard of Vox Machina or Critical Role. The only that drew me here is that I love animation especially aimed at mature crowd age. And I am far from disappointed I really liked it ! First invincible now this.The only small bit is that the story is a bit less mature, seems to be written by an in between teenager and an adult. But barring that aside great show.
This is sheer perfection. The world has been changed today, in the best way possible. Adaptations are often hit or miss. This sunk my battleship. This should never, ever, ever be canceled.

Second season just finished and my review hasn't changed much. A lot of fetch quests and strange storytelling for a series until you remember is all based on D&D campaigns, so the weird pacing somewhat makes sense. A new adult animated series on Amazon Prime created by Matt Mercer and his group Critical Role. I've followed Critical Role through Twitch for a good while now and I hadn't actually realized this series was based on those old D&D campaigns until recently, so of course I immediately decided to give it a watch. For those that don't know, Critical Role is a group of very fantastic voice actors in the film/tv/video game industries who all play D&D (and other games) live streamed on Twitch.tv. Matt Mercer stars as the dungeon master and uses his incredible story telling talents (and voice acting) to bring massive worlds to life. This new series, The Legend of Vox Machina, is an animated series following the first D&D campaign of that group as they team up to take down evil wizards, fight dragons, and save the city. Being created and starring the group that it does the voice acting is of course superb, and the humour brings over the same banter and quick wittedness the group has always offered; lots of f-bombs, farting, and chopping off heads. For anyone who at this point is at all interested in what I've said so far, I would say check this out, its only a single season so far so is fairly short, and was very entertaining the whole way through. It's sort of an Invincible but for a D&D based fantasy world. All that said, the general plotlines and backstories (which they are sure to rush through a bit for every character) aren't told incredibly deeply and often fit some pretty basic tropes of everyones first D&D campaign. That being said throughout the series you can almost imagine the real world group of players above the table, something that can either bring its own charm to the series or the opposite leave a bit of a narrative distaste when things fall a bit flat. In terms of "ragtag group of adventurers going off to save the world" series I've watched recently I'd have to say Andor > Willow > The Legend of Vox Machina > Dragon Age: Absolution > Witcher: Blood Origin, if that helps see about where it sits. It has its moments and was fun, almost as good as the 1983 Dungeons & Dragons animated series. Long live Venger!

reviews.review_title: You get exactly what you expect
reviews.content: If you are a CR fan you get exactly what you expect. Nothing more nothing less. I do think the show suffers from the fast pacing though and if you are not familiar with the characters from CR you do not really have time to get to know them. It is a love letter to the fans but not as great as Arcane was. Still great though.

reviews.review_title: The characters make the show, so it's good that it's all about them.
reviews.content: First off, I know about critical role and I've watched a good chunk of their 2nd campaign; so I have an idea of how this works. It's a DnD campaign, but select parts of it since animating the whole thing would have required 100+ episodes. This show is literally a dream come true for any DnD group. But since I have no prior knowledge of the 1st campaign this series is based on, I'm also not too blinded by expectations.The show is basically about an unlikely party of adventures doing DnD stuff. As this show doesn't cover any sort of back story of how they met, we're left to either speculate or watch the streams of the campaign. But even though we don't get any of that, the group is extremely fun and charming to watch. The show's humor is extremely ranchy and juvenile, and I love it. This is exactly how DnD games are: everyone just having fun with their characters and making the occasional dick joke then actually doing the objective if they have the time.The chemistry between characters also feels very natural, despite me not knowing much about their relationships besides the two siblings Vex and Vax. You can see the different levels of intimacy between different members. From the budding love between Keyleth and Vax, the close friendship between Grog and Pike, and a bunch of other more subtle dynamics. It's all very well rounded.The other characters aren't anything special, unfortunately. Other than the main villians of the Briarwoods, all the other characters are little more than props, comic relief, or flashy roadblocks. What I mean is, none of them are very interesting. Just their interactions with the party bring about interest.As for the plot, it's serviceable. The world building feels slightly phoned in, though. With the whole thing just feeling like a generic fantasy setting. Lots of the details on the Kingdom don't make sense if you think about it, too.Luckily, most of the plot involves a main character's backstory so it kept me engaged since this party was the only thing I really cared about in the show. It had many clichés, but I didn't find myself hating it since the whole adventure was still a joy to watch. The best parts were when the party needed to solve some sort of immediate problem and seeing how they did it was always hilarious and fun.The show probably isn't for everyone. I've seen many reviews bemoan the humor and the ranchiness, and I can see some people not being into it. All I know is that it, combined with the charm of the main cast, were the highlights. Even though the side characters and world building were pretty bad, it didn't matter to me since most of the show revolved around its best parts, Vox Machina.

reviews.review_title: One of the best shows ever made!
reviews.content: It's just amazing!Great humor, great voice acting, the animations and story is on point AF!Just can't think of ways to improve it ..so it's a 10/10 for me!
Episode 1 and 2 were a great set up and the 3rd showed what the season would look like. Compelling dialogue, amazing animation and perfect voice acting.
If you like animated series for adults, I recommend you to watch this tv show. A lot of violence and funny moments that make it a very good tv show. A lot of fantasy in a very violent environment.
This has the feeling of a really great Saturday morning cartoon that you used to watch, brought through time, and made for adults. I loved this. Its corny and rude and i loved every second of it!

reviews.review_title: A Promising Beginning and a Decent Show
reviews.content: The Legend of the Vox Machina is (as of the first three episodes) an authentic Critical Role series distilled into a half-hour of animation. It is crass, it is raunchy, it is violent, and it is grim. The trailers truly do not prepare you for the level of adult content in this series, and it does this well.I will admit, it will not be everyone's cup of tea. You will know if you want to continue by the end of the third episode, but I do implore that you watch it to the third episode. The first episode is very crass and raunchy. The second episode is very violent. Episode three, however, shows the true heart of the series once all the characters are introduced.Critical Role, and The Legend of the Vox Machina, are very character focused stories. Yes, there are grand plots surrounding them, but it is the characters that are the focus. And the characters are fun, charming, and engaging. Of course they are. The original 'script' was 'written' by a bunch of trained actors enjoying It is a bunch of actors who are also friends doing improve for four or so hours. So, when it came time to actually perform as these characters outside of the sessions, they had already played these characters for literal days' worth of time. 450 or so hours.Now, yes. There are issues. Episode one is a bit heavy on the crassness and the raunchy. Some of the writing is heavy handed in episode two. Despite this, it feels less like a consistent part of the series and more early installment weirdness or growing pains.It is a good series, and if it sounds like something you might enjoy, I do recommend it. The animation is beautiful, the character design incredible. The fight scenes are the complete opposite of half-done, and it is just a fun ride.For those Critters out there wondering how the series handles the source material, I will say that there are a lot of changes. How we meet the Vox Machina in the original streams verses when we meet them in the series. A lot had to be streamlined and a lot of fat cut, and I feel that these decisions were justified and best for the show.There was so much to the pre-streams that we missed. So much story, so much character, that starting in medias res would be confusion, and the audience would have to play catch up just to understand the history. Not only that, but the actual plot of the season starts 24 episodes into the original stream. Simplifying things makes it easier to consume and easier for new people to engage with the characters and story.Don't go into this expecting a perfect recreation of the episodes. It's simply not possible, not realistic, and utterly unfair to the hard work and passion poured into this show. Go into it with an open mind and enjoy the ride.

reviews.review_title: You'd think D&D fans would demand more
reviews.content: Yes, it is crude and purile. BUT animation can be crude AND still be funny, if there is some intelligence to the writing. (Archer being a prime example.) Vox, however, is just... stupid. After three episodes, there is nothing remotely smart, clever or compelling. At best, there are brief glimpses of promise or the momentary alure of mystery that only heightens the inevitable disappointment. This seems like a (poorly-crafted) insult to the D&D community. A swing and a huge miss so far. (And on no planet does this pile of mediocrity warrant a 9 on IMDB.)

I laughed through every episode of season one. Vox Machina is a riff on every fantasy series from LOTR to GoT; yet, it creates a fairly grounded world that is fresh and new. The animation serves the humor well, so if you like adult animation series this will be right up your alley. This a a perfect show for binging on weekend as there are not that many episodes. I am looking forward to season two.

I like swearing . But this program swears like a 10 year old that's just discovered swearing . Theres no nuance ,it's not clever . It's just spray the word F+ck into every sentence . It makes every character come across as as one dimensional idiots that defining characteristic is that they swear a lot . The rest of the plot is drowned by it .You don't have to swear In every sentence to entertain adults or to prove you are for adult viewers . In fact much like the 12 year old that things swearing makes them sound grown up it has the opposite effect.

I'm not a big fan of violence/cursing/potty humor/unnecessary crude behavior, and I was very unsure for the first half of the first episode, but things got better from there! Yes, some of the childish behaviour stays, but that's how the cast played it originally, so I can live with that. And the story really gets going in episode 3.until then, it's a liytle world and character buildingy, but considering the episodes are so short, it's not a problem.Looking forward to more!

reviews.review_title: Reminds me of University AD&D club
reviews.content: Endless evenings as a student in the 90s playing AD&D with my friends fueled by beer, tobacco and wotnot with a brilliant DM and a group of hilarious players. This show takes me right back and is all the better for being aimed at adults. Gone are tedious child friendly clichés and instead snappy writing, jokes, classic AD&D characters, monsters, villains & stories with little nods and winks to keep you smiling.More please.Vox Machina is strictly for adults and if you are one and this show still upsets you then other, tamer, shows are available. Try Peppa Pig.

reviews.review_title: Exactly what I was hoping for!
reviews.content: After watching campaign 1 and getting to know these characters for so long, this show is bang on! Probably too much to hope for, but I would love to see the show run the full plot of campaign 1.

reviews.review_title: Seems like they try to hard.
reviews.content: Everything tries so gosh darn hard to be cool, edgy and funny. That nothing is actually cool, edgy or funny.Seems like a cartoon that doesn't know what to be, 6 episodes in and it's quite boring. Mediocre animation but the voicework is good.Seems a lot of fanboys are giving 10's........imagine giving a 10 after a few episodes in.......fanboys ruin things.But it's all kind of mediocre right now, hope it will get better.

I'm a big fan of Critical Role. Everyone in the cast and crew, and guests, have a history of putting together a terrifically entertaining show, and churning out excellent fantasy storytelling. On a personal level, CR helped to get me through a dark period in my life, as has been true for many others. All the same, I think I have enough distance from the fandom to maintain a broader perspective on the company and everything they produce - and that also means 'The legend of Vox Machina,' perhaps their most ambitious endeavor since Critical Role's humble beginnings in 2015. What I see (in the first season) is a satisfying rendition of one of the most beloved story arcs of CR's first campaign, and of an additional story that took place before the stream began. I won't say that it's perfect - it's not - but I deeply admire the strong effort, and I think it's sufficiently well made that established fans, and viewers unfamiliar with the source material, can all enjoy the animated version.The extensive cast of LOVM is a treasure. Everyone that reprises their roles from the live stream show is a joy, of course - all professional voice actors, and it shows as they bring gratifying spirit and weight and to their performances as the adventuring party. Meanwhile, the list of people attached to fill supporting parts is flat-out impressive. It's a bit sad that not all are given the opportunity to truly illustrate their talents with the dialogue they are given, but all nonetheless turn in (thusly limited) portrayals that bring the characters to life and give a hint of their greater skill set. Among that supporting cast, Grey Griffin stands out above the others for an exceptional contribution: Delilah is as complex as she is villainous, and the venomous fire and gravity that Griffin brings to the part outshines everyone else who spent time in the (any) booth. Practiced as all are, hats off to veteran voice actor and director Mary Elizabeth McGlynn, herself a guest on CR many times over, for her guidance in realizing a story she knows so well.The animation is truly top-notch, as audiences have come to expect of Titmouse. The production here plainly recalls the fluid, natural, action-oriented style of the studio's most dynamic work, yet perhaps with a refined edge that shows not just the extraordinary budget that the whole operation had to work with, but the development of skills over many years - and, of course, the approach best suiting an epic fantasy story. The visualization of characters and settings previously seen only in our imagination, or in fan art or cosplay, are given beautiful, vivid form befitting the grandiosity of the tale imparted through Critical Role, but also of the genre at large. And when it comes to rapid movement, spellcasting, combat, blood and gore, and so on - I admit I don't tend to watch many cartoons, but I have a hard time believing that what we see here isn't representative of some of the very best to be found in 2022. This is a marvelous feast for the eyes, and with a core focus on horror violence for much of the first season, the visions before us are very satisfying for how unsettling they are.I think it's worth noting, though - as wonderful as the casting, voice work, and animation are, frankly the high quality was a foregone conclusion. There was no chance these aspects wouldn't dazzle, especially with the people involved. Of greater interest to me generally, and I think more important to assess here specifically, is the writing. How is the story? How is the adaptation of the saga fans know in such detail? Is this a series that can appeal to newcomers while still sating the hordes of "critters" that enthusiastically devour all the lore and content that CR, their collaborators, and fellow fans can serve up?Everyone in the writers' room had an immense task before them. Each episode of Critical Role, as a stream of a Dungeons & Dragons campaign, is anywhere from 3-5 hours long on average; a single combat encounter, seconds or minutes long in-game, may well last 1-2 hours in real time, or more. The Briarwood arc that constitutes 10 of the 12 half-hour episodes in the first season of 'The legend of Vox Machina' played out in about a dozen episodes on the stream. Shrinking that ponderous volume of story into a handful of hours of animation, adapting it for critters and uninitiated viewers alike, and doing so while keeping the heart of the narrative intact, was honestly an unenviable, daunting undertaking.Much more so than not, I think the writing team very well succeed in conjuring a satisfying rendition of these tales. Though I repeat myself, it's "critical" to remember that this is an adaptation: some beats and characters are effectively unchanged, while others are expanded or diminished in their significance or personality. Some facets and story beats are truncated, while others are omitted outright, or altered in favor of a new twist that better serves the format of a 30-minute cartoon. Some of the changes are less stimulating than the original presentation on the D&D live stream - while others are if not better, then at least just as delightfully electrifying. Without betraying spoilers, I think in particular of an encounter that the party has at their home before setting out to settle business with the Briarwoods. What we got on the game's stream was great - and though LOVM's take is different, in its own way it's equally awe-inspiring in the least, and certainly more viscerally horrifying.By and large, I think 'The legend of Vox Machina' is a tremendous endeavor that has paid off handsomely. Yet it's not without shortcomings. One does one's best to put aside the above-game shenanigans that have lent considerably to Critical Role's skyrocketing popularity from its very inception, and even the smaller moments to play out in-game apart from the core story arc. And still there is so much content we got in the streaming campaign that is sorely missed in this adaptation. I don't even mean specific proper nouns of the story - but rather, perhaps more substantially: the full emotional weight, the impact; the thrills, the dark dread, the utmost horror, the uncertainty, the tragedy, the love, the triumph, the pride. What shades of these notions LOVM delivers are mostly just that - shades, mere slivers of not just what we got in the live stream, but of what storytelling as an art form should convey. Furthermore, with rare exception, the cutting complexity of the characters has been reduced to a decidedly simplified interpretation that struggles to spark the imagination. Some character traits, character development, interactions between characters (the principles in particular), and some story beats have been both condensed and amplified to an extent that is unmistakably artificial and forced (e.g. Keyleth's growth; Vex's haughtiness; a budding relationship). And while as a fan of Critical Role it's hard not to smile at small references to other moments that canonically took place elsewhere in the story of Vox Machina, or in the story of The Mighty Nein in the stream's second campaign - I'm just not sure that these are always woven in organically, or convincingly.I think my criticism boils down to two points. Firstly, in trying to adapt and open the saga to the widest possible audience, the writing scales down every aspect of the storytelling, yet in so doing tips its hand too far and trims away some of those very elements of what makes the tale of these ragtag adventurers so endearing and rewarding in the first place. And secondly, to some measure, LOVM feels purely like fan service. I believe LOVM would be entertaining and worthwhile for a CR neophyte, but the necessary abridgement of the narrative extends to the characters that are a part of it, and the feelings that it should stir in us. However much 'The legend of Vox Machina' may be enjoyed by someone who has never watched so much as a fan-made highlight video of an episode of Critical Role - it also comes across as a passion project to retell the same story in a new medium for fans who already have the context to most appreciate the reimagining, and all its flourishes, regardless of whether any given moment has been reshaped with all due meaningfulness.In fairness: as events escalate in the latter half of the season, the writing broadens to allow every charged emotion to feel more momentous, nearer to what it should.
