They were well-timed, genuinely funny, and the most important part, spread out. Hearing Scanlan say a handful of dirty jokes over the course of 3-4 hrs is nothing. But hearing 20 dirty jokes in the span of 20 minutes? It just feels childish and like it's trying way too hard to be for Adults. I genuinely hate the character Scanlan in this show when I actually liked him in the stream. But they've made him unbearable in the tv adaption and I'm not sure why. But it's bad.Second: the animation.The animation is stiff as heck. Like REALLY stiff. It honestly looks like a fan animation. Reminds me of that person who animated like the first 10 books of a kids book series all by themself. But that was impression because one person did it. This? A billionaire company and thousands of fundings from fans to produce.. this? It's actually astounding how bad it is. I've seen cartoons that were 80+ years old that move more fluidly. Animation is supposed to get better with time (and money), and yet this just looks like a dumpster fire. Not to mention all but 2 characters designs are ugly as sin and look nothing like the original art used in the stream.Third: the pacing.The pacing in this show is godawful. It moves at a breakneck speed. Within the first few minutes they've killed a dragon and became members of a royal council. Like huh? Let's slow down here for sec! I think we've missed a few major steps here. There's so many scenes that have been cut for time when a lot of them are integral. For example, Percy crafts Vex an explosive arrow in the stream. They have a conversation about it and he basically says he'd do anything to please her. This scene gives us some insight into how Percival feels about Vex. In the show however, the arrow is bought in a rushed shopping scene and it's over within a minute. I understand that they are having to cut a lot out to make it fit into a 20-30 min episode and I would be able to forgive them for this if they didn't cut out scenes, only to add some in that NEVER happen in the stream. Like Scanlan singing about his "beads of love" during the middle of an emotional fight scene. But I digress. The point being, the show moves way too fast and it's genuinely hard to keep up if you don't already know what's going on.Fourth: the voice acting.I'm genuinely surprised at how Bad a lot of the voice work is. Scanlan sounds like he's from a badly dubbed anime. Grog sounds like dumb child, constantly mispronouncing words like "dat", "widdle", "pwease". He's supposed to be cockney, not 5. And Keyleth's voice is extremely whiny and her dialogue lasts too long because it's full of excessive stuttering. These are all professional voice actors who did amazing jobs while on stream. But in the studio? Apparently, they aren't very good I'm finding out. It's appalling.There's many more things wrong with this show but this is all I can think of for now.I know this was a passion project for CR and all that and they really wanted it to work. But it just goes to show you, just because someone has been in a lot of tv shows, doesn't automatically mean they can make one. I see now why they are voice actors and not directors. I shudder to think what season 2 will be like.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful and refreshing animated dark comedy
reviews.content: The series talk about the adventures and misadventures of the group Vox Machina, a hilarious comedy with a new component in each episode that's make you want to see all episode in one round.
Had high hopes for this show. It met them. Felt good. Also lots of male genetalia jokes. Can't wait for the whole show to be released. Also season 2. 10/10.

I had high hopes for the the legend of vox machina and it has surpassed everything I wanted it to be, being both hilarious and gloriously violent at the same time. The upcoming Whitestone story arc is somewhat of a darker tale and it will be very interesting to see how the series handles this, very well if the first three episodes are benchmark I believe that it will be even better.

reviews.review_title: A quirky show to watch on the side, but overhyped
reviews.content:
I have currently watched 9 episodes, as the last three haven't been released yet, so my review will obviously only take into account what has been released so far.I will also try to not put in spoilers and talk about this as generally as possible.So first of all, I am not a fan of Critical Role and I have not watched the original campaigns. I do however have many friends that are huge fans of the series, so I was roughly aware of the premise.From what I gathered, the general consensus of the fanbase has been very positive, and I am very happy for them! I will however look at this from the perspective of someone with no real ties to the source material and just talk about my opinions on this as an animated series first and foremost.The premise of the adventure is pretty generic, with a mostly stereotypical cast of characters. You have an awkward druid, a horny halfling (?) bard, a (trying to be) suave half elf and his greedy sister, a serious dude with a gun, a dumb big guy with a heart of gold and another halfling cleric who seems to struggle with her god.THE GOOD:The art: The characters in the show look pretty. The backgrounds are gorgeous. The animation is not mind blowing and cannot compare with things like Legend of Korra or Castlevania, but it is decent enough! Knowing this was funded by kickstarter money, I am impressed because this looks polished and like something I could see on television. Some of the 3D looks outdated (especially in episode 1), but that is fine considering the budget they probably had.The intro: The intro is gorgeous. The animation of the show is not as good as the intro, like in many animes, but I actually found myself searching for it on youtube just because I wanted to see it again.Staying faithful to the original: As far as I understand from my friends, nothing has been changed too much in this adaptation lore-wise, and I can respect that! Nice!Voice acting: The voice acting is pretty decent. Some of the main cast are AMAZING and sound very genuine (Scanlan, Pike, Vex, Percy), but there are others that sound a bit too.. Over the top. A bit too much like a generic anime dub, and that breaks my immersion a bit (Vax, Grog and Keyleth at times). Some of the character interactions are genuinely funny though, and I like that the conversations between the heroes do sound organic, with the constant banter back and forth.The music: The music is decent. The main theme is memorable enough.THE OK:
The story: The story is very generic in my opinion and the character arcs as well. It's not bad per se, but it's not something that instantly hooked me either. I was mostly just hooked by the premise of "DnD show made into a cartoon by kickstarter money". It doesn't really stand out yet. The first three episodes suffer from the shaky legs syndrome, where the pacing feels a bit all over the place. The first one is filled with cringey things during the introduction, but I assume it is there to introduce the audience to the general "yes this isn't censored, we actually put this in" vibe.For better or worse, very dependant on what you want to see from this show. After those first 3 episodes it does pick up though.THE BAD AND UGLY - Direction, Length of the Episode and the Adult Content:Ok. I have a lot of problems with the show. It's not the worst show I've seen, but also not the best. It's... Ok.My biggest gripe with the entire series is that it tries to stand out because it's an "adult show".Now, here's the thing: The show has A LOT of cringey and yucky scenes and does not shy away from crude jokes, hinting at genitalia, sex and gore, but it does not make it feel adult. In fact, somehow despite all of this, it feels incredibly childish BECAUSE of that. This is the kind of humor pubescent teenagers like, period. And that's okay, but hyping it up as an "adult show" with these themes does not cut it. It is simply a very vulgar show.There are hints of adult themes in this that felt serious at first, but then the direction of the episodes usually fell really flat.The biggest problem of this series IS the Direction. I am going to try and explain it:
The way a show treats its audience, indicates heavily if it's for adults or not. Cartoons for kids for example will usually try to chew things out for you, show very obvious scenes and metaphorically push your nose into the plot. Shows for adults on the other hand do things much more discreetly. They will hint at things here and there, and give you the opportunity to read between the lines, and maybe even theorize yourself. "Show - Don't Tell" is where a good adult show shines.The Legend of Vox Machina does not really do this (well). It is directed like a kids show, to put it simply. Flashbacks are shown too early, a character's distress will be shown directly in relation to a completely new element that is introduced, and you get to the narrative conclusion in your head about 3 minutes into the episode. As a viewer, you don't really get the chance to be shocked or surprised, because the plot points play out in such an obvious way. The audience is basically treated like dummies.As an example: Avatar was a show for kids with none of the sexual innuendos TLoVM had, and it felt miles and miles more mature than this.If I had to guess, a big reason for this silly direction is probably the length of the episodes. 20 minutes seem enough at first glace, with how long the episodes *feel*, but that is because it's trying to rush through most of the plot in a more superficial way without appealing to emotional storytelling beats. It is in my opinion nowhere near enough to establish all of these plot points in an actual satisfying way though. This really dampened my enjoyment unfortunately.In conclusion, I think it's ok. It's nothing special (except the fact it was made with kickstarter funding and is based on a dnd show) and it does not come near other western animation like Netflix Castlevania or Arcane, both in animation or narratively. Story and pacing wise, there is still a lot to improve. It's good enough to kill time with, or maybe use it as a teaser to get into the actual DnD show, which is much more compelling and complex as I understand. A good way to imrpove it imo would be less episodes, but make them about 40 minutes each. Don't try to imitate anime or a specific media, just try to make a good film/show.I don't really understand the high rating and I assume it must be the excited fanbase, but perhaps I am simply too critical. This is after all, just my subjective opinion.Tl;dr: This is a fun, quirky, light hearted show with cringe humor but pleasant art. It's good for popcorn cinema, but don't expect a masterpiece of storytelling from this.

Very good adaptation from the D&D campaign to animation. Good character development and story already at the start and fantastic action scenes. Fulfilled all my expectations and incorporated D&D mechanics and campaign moments wonderfully. Needless to say, the voice acting is phenomenon. Overall an absolute joy to watch and re-watch.

Cheap animation, bland graphic style, silly sex jokes, ultra generic characters and intrigues.... What else? I watched the first 3 episodes and i surely won't watch the others coming...
the only positive thing comint out of this show is that i miss the original dongeon&dragon animated serie.

reviews.review_title: 8.9 Are you kidding? Well, based on the idiotic humor it has, you probably are
reviews.content: I like fantasy. I like light hearted fun. I like good humor. I like adventure flicks.However, the humor in this series is sooo bad, immature, lame, childish, forced that it ruins the whole experience.I give it 5 point because I'm curious about the whole world and the lore, and maybe the characters too but the humor is so freaking bad I watch it cringing almost all the time (yes, that much humor they use).

reviews.review_title: The Legend of Vox Machina season 1 (2022, Amazon Prime/Critical Role) Great adult fantasy animation entertainment
reviews.content: 'Vox Machina' is a 12 episode animated fantasy series that debuted on the Amazon Prime Video streaming service in January of 2022. One of the more fascinating things about this production has nothing to do with what you see on screen. Instead how the production came to be is at least as interesting as the rollicking fantasy adventure. There is a group of D&D players called Critical Role who turned a D&D campaign into a very successful, if somewhat niche, podcast. Those folks then launched a Kickstarter to produce an animated special and it was so wildly successful that the special became a legit show with the streaming rights acquired by Amazon.The show features a band of 7 adventurers in the land of Tal'Dorei seeking fame, gold, wine, women and song; all of the things classic adventure groups crave. It is a prototypical group featuring such character archetypes as druid, warrior, ranger, cleric and the like although it does dawn on me with some astonishment that there group does not possess a traditional mage. The bulk of the show has to do with the intrepid group investigating the mysterious Lord and Lady Briarwood who have taken over the city/land of Whitestone. One of their group, Percy, was a lord in Whitestone as a child before the Briarwood's came along with their contingent and slaughtered his family so now he and the rest of his Vox Machina crew are looking for answers and vengeance. There are various side quests and plots, but all of those serve this primary narrative. All of the dominoes steadily fall with some twists and turns as Vox Machina close in on the Briarwoods and find out the nature of their secrets as well as some dark secrets of their own.This show is a heck of a lot of fun. It is cool as a kid to be enamored with the old Dungeons & Dragons cartoon and now flash forward to adult hood and there is a much grittier adult style take on that cartoon. 'Vox Machina' doesn't bare much resemblance to that old cartoon, but the D&D link connects them in my mind. 'Vox Machina' is much more adult animation and doesn't shy away from swearing, violence, dark thematic material or nudity. Another great aspect to the show is its humor. While I wouldn't strictly lump it into the comedy genre this does have a lot of funny, comedic elements to counterbalance the darker violence and adventure tones as well. Only one season into its run 'The Legend of Vox Machina' has already been renewed for two more seasons. If you have any interest in adult fantasy then this is not a show to miss.Eric's Grade: A-

The show is in desperate need of better writing. The dialogue is generic and the scenarios felt bland. Maybe I would enjoy this more if I was a D&D player, but I feel a good story should be able to stand on it's own.

I'm coming at this review from a specific viewpoint. As a person who already loves CR and happens to think Campaign 1 is the best of the three.The animation is very nice. As a person who doesn't watch a lot of animated stuff however, my knowledge is limited. I have enjoyed Final Space, Arcane, and Invincible however, and found the style to be of the same quality. (Not on the level of Arcane, but what is?)The plot is a tricky one, as I already know it. It moves a lot quicker than the live stream, but of course it has to. They don't have 400 hours like before. I do find it very compelling, the characters are fantastic and it's such a good feeling to finally see these people that I love come to life in this way.As is to be expected, the voice acting is superb. Not just the main cast, but everyone does a fantastic job. If you have watched CR before there will be Easter eggs for you to find and some funny DnD references to look out for.The Briarwood arc was something very, very special in campaign one (even though Percy is my least favourite member). And the talent these guys have assembled, and the love they have poured into this show is evident in every frame.Yes it has blood and swearing, and no. It isn't suitable at all for children. But is it childish? No.It's like real life, most of the time we are trying to keep things fun and positive. We laugh when we can. But there is some heart in this too, and knowing where it goes, it's going to get very emotional.Absolutely love this show so far, I'll be rewatching it a few times no doubt. If you dig fantasy, or DnD, or swords and sorcery. Like I do, give it a go. You'll probably be very pleasantly surprised.

Where to start?Bad writing, cliche stories, tired old tropes, the people behind the laughable campaign malign every good Dungeon Master out there.For one thing, this should have been set in Greyhawk or Faerun. Homebrew is a terrible way to try to show Dungeons & Dragons(D&D).Voice acting was awful, overly filled with people trying to out do each others next line.Pacing and story board structure was full of bad tempo.As someone who grew up with and played D&D with the inventor Gary Gygax himself, he is spinning in his grave over this treatment of his beloved game.

Characters a spot on and love the feel. Bit too much swearing sorta takes you out of a fantasy world a bit but other than that perfect.love the animation so spot on for what I expected and I expected alot from This and it been waiting so long looking forward to this.

reviews.review_title: Fans of Critical Role - You know what to expect and it delivers
reviews.content: I stumbled across CR and die laughing. When this first came out I had no idea what it was and didn't give it a shot until I found out that it was CR made to an animated series.Those guys are just all around awesome and insanely funny people. These episodes are taken from the CR series. If you were/are a fan of them, you'll enjoy this without fail.

Season one is a slightly above average story that doesn't really shine anywhere but is still good enough see the potential of a good show. The characters get better as the show goes on and you start knowing them but the character development is very slow. I have mixed feelings on the characters, Percy and Pike are great and have nice backstory. Keyleth and the twins are likeable and cool but they're not really developed. The humor is either Grog being dumb or Scanlan cursing, they're not great. The story is nothing special as it's just a group of warrior doing quest, it's not bad but there isn't much substance for the first half. Not much is explained, you're thrown in the show and expected to care, I've learned later why but I've not seen Critical Role so it wasn't great for me. The animation is pretty standard but the action is pretty good, it's probably the highlight of the season.Season two is an improvement on pretty much every level, apart from the animation who's still pretty standard. The characters were likeable by the end of the season and now they're great for the whole season, apart from Scanlan who's still pretty annoying. Grog is the most improved elements of the show, he has a good backstory in the season and becomes more than a comedic relief. The twins also got a backstory which was pretty interesting and Keyleth was used more as a character, the rest of the characters were as good as before. On a story level it's much better, there's not a lot of boring moments and every episodes have something to offer.Season 1: 6.5/10
Season 2: 7.5/10.

You can see this was made with a sense of passion for D&D, by people who love what they do. It's fun and well made. A great mix of quirky, diverse and interesting characters, simple but intriguing stories. One for us D&D nerds but open for almost anyone... not kid friendly though.

Only the first three episodes have been released so far, but that's plenty of time for the cast and crew to show off their chops. As a fan of the original critical role campaign, I was confident this show would be good, but I wasn't sure how much of the original story would have to be sacrificed to get everything down to a reasonable length for TV.I need not have worried. I should've known that no one knows or cares more about the story of Vox Machina than the players who created them. Not only is the show 100% loyal to the personalities of the characters and the energy of the show, it also manages to preserve the most impactful moments from the campaign with practically perfect fidelity.I can't recommend this show enough.

I'm a big fan of Critical Role, I watched every seasons so far, but I really find this animated serie horrible. It's like they are trying too much. It feels really forced. The voices are not natural, they sounds very caricatural, like If every sentences had to make a big impression, it feels like I'm at the theatre. The constant juvenile jokes are also really heavy and annoying, it's like I'm watching an improved version of Looney Tunes. Even the story is very simple. I just don't have the good vibes that I have with critical role. I know it's not the same format but I was hoping to find the same pleasure watching it.

This has popped up enough on Amazon suggestions and I always discard it. Saw a list on here of Shows of D&D and the next time I saw it, I selected it.I watched about 5 episodes the first time playing it (they are all short) and found myself enjoying it much to my surprise. I really expected to drop it like I do midway through a latest installment of Jackazz.The story themes are a lot like a session of D&D, not a bad thing. The banter is a lot like you find with a group of friends while playing DDO. The actors seemed to know each other quite well. Reading a bit more about it, they have been doing this together for years. It shows in a good way. There is a lot of creativity in the world of D&D so they won't lack for material. I expect this to be very good for a long time.The bad: The quantity of "adult humor" is overboard. It comes of as "We're not a kid show, really!" Throw a bit in once in a while and it would be effective without desperation.Mixed bag: The writing is good almost always but does rely on.worn tropes, which I was expecting so wasn't a problem. It just seems like it came from their sessions. The "bad guy" in the first couple episodes did trick me even if it seemed obvious after.Overall it is a fun watch with quick episodes that keep you interested. I gave it a 6 when I first started writing this but bumped it to a 7 before clicking submit. As they refine things in future seasons it could become an 8 and a 7 for cartoons is high praise from me. I am on episode 2 of season 2.

I love CR. I laugh, cry, rage and cheer of joy with the live streams. This however did not feel right to me at all. The animation style, given the money they had from fans and Amazon, was not as good as it should have been. The storytelling was off, the pacing just felt wrong aswell. I wish i could be more positive about it, but i can't.

reviews.review_title: It's fantastic - well worth the wait
reviews.content: I've been waiting for this series for 3 years now and I've been a fan of the webseries well before that. It's funny, touching, violent and sincere - everything I was hoping for.

reviews.review_title: Quite easily the worst thing I've ever seen.
reviews.content: Juvenile and disgusting humor, jarring shifts in tone from goofy (and immature) to serious (and unconvincing), combined with shallow and unlikeable characters. The Legend of Vox Machina is a show for people who pretend to like tabletop roleplaying games but have not ever played anything beyond Hasbro's hijacking of the hobby.Actual roleplayers will be confronted with a show that is clearly just the presentation of one particularly bad group's personal roleplaying game story, presented in offensive and in-your-face cartoonish style to really drive home how childish this inappropriately offputting show actually is.

This show is funny, creative, and just overall amazing. I had no other context to this show about it being tied to something with DnD but think it was fantastic non the less. Can't wait for more episodes!!!

reviews.review_title: Really bad adaptation of a good twitch/youtube show
reviews.content: I had some expectations for this but what makes the original show good is lost in translation in the animated series. Having professional actors in a dnd settings and watching them roleplay, improv and play off each others in different situations is what made critical role something worth watching. Once You remove all those good things you end up with a subpar story for a subpar animated series. I really didnt feel like watching an adult show if it wasnt for the unnecessary gore and swear words..

I'm trying to like Vox Machina but it's just not clicking. I find the animation lackluster and attempts at humor somewhat forced. I do like the gore. Idk, guess I've been removed from D&D longer than i thought. I still watching, so I gave it a 5.

Nice with some adult entertainment literally speaking. Really captured the spirit of Vox Machina and went all in: Gory, nasty jokes, nudity, did I mention gory! Vox Machina is such a lovelly bunch of misfits but with a tad of heart. Story starts with a bang and then keeps going, jokes are sharp and childish and the action brutally delightful. Having a blast so far!

reviews.review_title: A heartfelt, beautiful, well-made animated series
reviews.content: This is a wonderful show. Many of the negative reviews seem to focus on the profanity and explicitly violent and sexual nature of the show, including one that gave 1 star simply for not being appropriate for kids. It is true. The show has nudity, violence, and profanity, but the promotional material does not attempt to conceal this. If non child appropriate media isn't your jam, don't watch it. But also don't drag a show for being exactly what it promised and not adherent to your personal values.This show is hilarious, emotionally charged, and full of BEAUTIFUL animation. The voice acting is superb and the script is tight.

reviews.review_title: Decent Animation and great voice acting but that is pretty much it.
reviews.content: The animation is decent, the bgm and voice acting is great. The plot, character development and script is terrible. Just including profanity, gore and some nudity does make an adult show. The character themselves have no depth, they are as stereotypical as possible. The comedy is completely in the line of toilet humor. The biggest problem of all is how cringe the dialogues are and how terrible the interactions are, i would imagine this is what a teenager believes adult speak like.If they spent sometime developing the characters and asked some moral questions while making fun of their situation, it would make for a better show with more adult themes. With the way the first three episodes are, I have pretty low expectation for the rest of it.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good but what was that start
reviews.content:
Start = bad. It just does. Way too rushed but whatever.16.6% of the show is 10/10
33.3% of the show is 9/10
25% of the show is 8/108.3% of the show is 6/10
8.3% of the show is 5/10
8.3% of the show is 1/10The briarwood arc is brilliant. The humour, especially in the first ghastly episode, is very immature and childish but there are moments when it is quite good, i.e. See the scene spent on the door. When the show is more subtle with the humour, the better it is.First 3 episodes are incredibly rushed and Grieg's fight has no weight to it since we don't know who this guy is nor do we care about him or the rest of the cast.This show is made for the fans obviously and it's meant to be a testament to how brilliant this group of DND players are, but for anyone new watching, they should really just skip over the first few episodes and just watch the Briarwood arc. Sure you might be missing some context for initial character relationships but you'll get that anyway in later episodes. And by god, missing the gratuitous caricature of what could be called a pilot episode is worth it to get to the marvelous writing that is the Briarwood arc.

The absolute best adaptation of a Dungeons and Dragons campaign yet. It's brilliant, fun, fast-paced, violent, and just hilarious. Packed with easter eggs for hard-core Critters out there, while for new fans the story is engaging, characters are anything but bland and have room to grow. Simply a very fun show.

As a fan of Critical Role but also objectively as an interested animation viewer I love the vibe of the series. Dark and horrifying when it needs to be interlaced with comic relief. Personal development of the characters, cliffhangers and good adult entertainment and incredible attention to detail merging western animation with anime.
Now THIS is worth your time. If you're an adult and you like D&D, or any RPG/Fantasy at all really, check this out. Absolutely hilarious animated series. Stop reading and just give it a go!

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable and worth a watch for fantasy fans
reviews.content: Great for new people unfamiliar with the story and the characters if you don't mind the vulgarity and also amazing for long time fans. The characters feel fleshed out and everyone gets their chance to shine. The animation isn't anything new (classic Phil Bourassa design) but with added character. The soundtrack is honestly amazing and deserves a listen on its own, really elevates the series. The story may feel rushed and roughly paced at the beginning but it really amps up after episode 2.

reviews.review_title: How to take 10 hour and make it a 30 minute show
reviews.content: To ever one saying this is to catering to the fan of critical role look at you funded it we the fan this is how shows should be made. They made a show that struck by the original material the same kind of jokes andthe same kind of pacing and relationship building that it's all based off of. So how can you leave a Low review because something follows the material The show was not made for the masses it was made for the people that tune in every week made for every fan of DND it was made to bring forth more interest this shows the essence of DNd being in a room with your friends making bad jokes building a world together.

After reading some of the reviews I've seen many mentions of the "inappropriate" language and a perceived rushed aspect of the show, the aforementioned I find very silly in contrast to the violence and the latter I agree with to some extent.Vox Machina was funded by its creators and then got picked up by Amazon as a basically finished product, so they condensed a compelling story arc to fit within the budget that they had. If it gets picked up for another (preferably longer) season then we will get to know the characters beyond their façade.What's interesting with a series based on a campaign spanning years is that first-off there's so much material to draw from and secondly that the "writer" of this show did not create his main protagonists. In D&D every character has their own writer and therefore they all inhabit their own style. This makes for a natural motley crue that feels truly alive.If you wish to see something truly amazing take its first steps then I recommend you watch Vox Machina.

reviews.review_title: If I could vote 0 stars I could...
reviews.content: This show is terrible. I couldnt even get through the first 10 minutes because every 10 seconds there was an f bomb, or other unnecesary language. Also, full on cartoon nudity? Wtf?! I shut it off when the green gnome creature was eating out the green elf lady. Absolutely disgusting. How this has 9 stars overall is a mystery to me! Stay away, especially if you want a wholesome fantasy show.

Half of these reviews are garbage reviews made by garbage people.The people who have reviewed the series without any knowledge of source material- trash. The people offended by swearing-trash. The people who just don't know how to sit back and enjoy something-trash. This show is fun and stays true to the source materials, at the time of this only 6 episodes had been released and you have clowns writing off the season without knowing what happens next.

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like it, but just can't.
reviews.content: This show is essentially sheer ego stroking.After years of having hundreds of thousands of people sit around while they filmed hundreds of 4+ hour episodes where you got the privilege of watching trained voice actors play DnD around a table, and making bazillions on their Kickstarter, clearly the fame got to their head. Now it's more about them than the characters, the plot or the setting.So, if you want to watch anime style animation that doesn't jive with a bunch of Millennial and Gen Z slang that could have dropped right out of any modern, hip, sitcom or web series, so none of their dialogue fits at all ... be my guest.If you want sarcastic, snide Millennial and Gen Z insults and humour to pepper the whole thing, so it's like you're sitting on a bus, surrounded by university students making fun of each other ... be my guest.If you want to marvel at the clumsily introduced EDI inserts that are so literally scripted and dropped in that you cannot but think that they were literally working to a checklist ... be my guest. I especially loved the bearded magic shop owner in gaudy, Romani style make up, the pansexual gnome that can't keep it in his pants for more than 30 seconds, or - the piece de resistance - the 'master hunter' in a wheel chair. I mean, seriously, how do you get to be a master hunter when you can't even go into the forest? Onto a mountain? Do four of them carry him in the wilderness so that he can feel like he fits in? When you feel you need to insert this nonsense into a fantasy story where it clearly sticks out like a 21st century identity politics it is, you're missing the point of being a storyteller.Above and beyond that, the pacing is just ridiculous. You drop right in the middle of the first campaign and you're literally in the middle of the celebration of their victory when the attack that drives the second campaign hits. Sure, it's based on some actual DnD campaigns, but come on, let them get a beer. Give the audience a bit of a denouement.So, I made it about half way into the second season and then called it quits. I know all kinds of people who watched the original Critical Role series and loved it, and they also love Vox Machina, but they are all 20 years my junior and they couldn't give a fig about character, plot or setting. Just be sarcastic and charming and entertaining and they will worship the ground you walk on, to the tune of 12M buckaroos. You don't need to be good at telling a story or playing a role, you just have to be audacious. Apparently.No thanks. Even my own DnD campaign has more maturity than this lot.

reviews.review_title: Luckily not a natural 1, unfortunately not a natural 20 either
reviews.content:
While most certainly biased, this review aims to be as objective as possible.The show may very well be characterized as fan service, for better or worse.A lot of the jokes simply won't hit the same without knowing the source material or other geek subculture factoids.A good chunk of those jokes won't hit at all, but rather fly over the heads of people who ended up watching it randomly or by proxy.Personally, I do not think this makes the show worse or better. It is the way they chose to go and the reception to that has been mixed by fans and newcomers alike.The voice acting is the best component of the show. All of these people have been in the business for decades and it is evident.If you like video games and animated shows but know nothing of the cast, you might very well have moments where you listen to the character voices, certain you have
heard them before, but unable to pinpoint from where.Or in case of characters voiced be Mercer... your reaction would be more along the lines of "HOW IS THAT THE SAME PERSON?!"The pacing is off. This is something everyone, including the cast, seems to agree on. The first two episodes are the worst of the bunch in that regard.This is most likely the result of the cast expecting the project to be much smaller in scope when the kickstarter happened, and the result of cramming dozens of hours of
DnD sessions into a 30ish minute animated episode. It is not nearly as bad later on in the season. Probably because the remaining episodes of the season focus
on a different arc, resulting in more time to tell the story.On the subject of story, adamantly wanting to avoid spoilers, I will only say that it is great. This is a matter of personal preference, however.You will have to look elsewhere for further insight into it.The writing however, is again, hit and miss. A good chunk is not only lifted directly from the sessions, but improved upon due to hindsight and retrospect.It is much weaker in some episodes. (again, the first two) and feels very much like it picks up the slack in episodes written later on.(Sam Riegel, Travis Willingham, Ashley Burch and Marc Bernardin did awesome work)The animation is very mixed too. The worst of it comes from the mixture of 3D and 2D animation done at the same time resulting in such a terrible clash on screen.It is almost disappointing and may very well pull you out of it, especially the first few times it happens. Luckily, the 2D animation by itself ranges from
average to absolutely impressive.One thing I will admit and have discussed with other critters is how much more brutal the show was than we expected. While the nudity and sex related content
(which are always done as a joke or simply a funny scene) are a factor in classifying it as an adult show. It pales in comparison to the blood and gore visuals,
which are done without the tongue-in-cheek factor the former thrives on.All things considered, I find recommending the show depends very much on your taste, interests, and how repulsive you find the visuals.I've been looking forward to it since it was announced, and it actually pains me to give it a 7. I chose to do so because there is much room for improvement.Hopefully it is a matter of the team settling in into the format and it is only uphill from here.

reviews.review_title: Azula's voice actor on the show
reviews.content: I'm enjoying watching this show because the actor who play Delilah Briarwood is same actor who is play Azula from Avatar The Last Airbender. The show is extremely awesome. I hope can see more seasons of this awesome show.

reviews.review_title: Finally a work of fantasy fiction for table top RPG fans!
reviews.content: A wonderful show that anyone with actual table top role playing game experience can relate to. Filled with an all star cast of some of the most talented voice actors in the industry. I need more seasons!

If I hadn't seen the campaign before the animation I would've liked this series far more. Unfortunately they changed the story so much it had little to do anymore with what I watched before, apart from the characters and the Briarwood storyline, more or less. I'm certain there are many people who have no problem with that, but I'm not one of them.Combine that with the use of certain tropes I've already gotten quite tired of seeing has led to this rating.So if you have no problem with watching the Briarwood campaign but quite different, go watch this. But if you're more like me, don't.

Finally great animated fantasy series for adults what is in every aspect good if not great! Funny! Good characters witch showing growth apart of some but I guess you can't make one season about every main character! Good storyline! Action in every episode but it's not forced! Gore, foul language and sex witch show that real life is no fairy tale for kids but also didn't over did it! Everything you think of when you looking for great fantasy cinematography experience this series have! I have watched through that in one sitting and I wish to see more series well done like this one. Definitely wort to watch and I'm inpatient for next season.

It definitely is for a mature audience but what a show.It is funny, full of adventure. The team behind the show are well aware of what a D&D adventure should look like.Can't wait for the second season.
Good writing and amazing voice acting ofcourse. Never seen the Vox Macina campaign but this series gives you a great peak at their group dynamic.Cant wait for season 2.

reviews.review_title: Proud of the critical role team, but the show falls flat
reviews.content: I've been a fan of CR for 2 years and watched much of camaign 2 and 3 as well as EXU.While Im so glad to see the CR team produce a show and all the kindness thrown their way, this does not meet the standards of your typical show.As someone who watches quite a lot of anime and general TV, this show lacks what is needed to craft a well established show.The pacing is very fast, the characters do not spend time to get developed, and the emotional gravity fluctuated quickly. Voice acting is amazing as you'd expect, but as a stand alone, this show feels more like an ode to CR and their achievements than a digestible fantasy show for the mass market.If you are a fan of CR, I highly recommend this show to enjoy their vision and support them, but if you see a score of 9 on IMDB and think wow this is going to be the next big thing, I think you will be sorely disappointed.Its got good voice acting, some hit or miss comedy, ok action and gore, and a off the rails pace. If you compare this to the likes of Arcane, or fantasy shows like Re:Zero, this show feels lacking.

reviews.review_title: Not the D&D R rated cartoon I expeted
reviews.content: First I have never listened to any Critical Role. The Animation is great, story is decently written and acting is pretty damn good. My problem is they spent two episodes fighting a Dragon and the rest of the series is a Vampire Psychodrama. They blew their load on the first two and it was downhill from there for me. It did feel as if there where dice rolls dictating the events. Love Laura Bailey but I was not expecting an English Accent, was hoping she would be using her Keiko voice. Worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Check the rating Before letting your 13 year old Daughter watch it.
reviews.content: My daughter put this on While eating breakfast. I walked in the door as a Gnome Bard seduces and goes down on an Elf Bar maid. My daughter shot milk out her nose. Beautiful art style and voice acting.

reviews.review_title: I laughed, I cried, and I want MORE!!!
reviews.content: It's just like listening or watching them play on the tabletop, Only now we can see what the characters would look like in the world Exandria. The cast, crew, producers and everyone involved put that crowd funding to good use and we are blessed to have an amazing product at the end, which hopefully is not only loved by fans, but also by newcomers as well, as there's so much to love and there's always the original content they have from the table top as well. If there's one negative thing, it's that there will always be a want for more and having to wait for another episode is just like having to wait another week for critical role to have another session. Is it Sunday yet.

reviews.review_title: A promising IP with a lot of room to grow.
reviews.content: Given the nature of fandom I will say up front I am a Critical Role fan. In that regard the series already satisfies what many of us fantasied about since the inception of the actual play. However for a review from a more objective stand point continue reading.Only three episodes have been released so far, so if I can edit my review after the release of the entire season I will. Also know upfront, this isn't a show for kids or the prudish.Episode 1 introduces to us the characters at a time when they are down on their luck, most of the episode is given to developing the characters and does an ok job. The first couple episodes suffer from pretty severe tonal whiplash at times. It also sets up an overly humorous atmosphere which I don't think translates as well in a purely narrative endeavor compared to the kind of table humour an actual play series can sustain. That said the third episode really got the balance right in my opinion and I expect sets the standard for what we'll see going forward given what I know about the events to come.In between all of that though were some really heartfelt emotional and inspirational moments pretty typical of the fantasy genre. The show certainly leans into its tabletop roots with the story telling and action pieces which I'm sure will delight many and probably put off a few at the same time.The first mini arc contained within episodes 1 and 2 really feels a little rushed and I do wonder how well those episodes will hook in viewers who aren't already acquainted with the characters. The story itself is quite generic for the genre, though this is typical of many introductory stories where you're trying to set up the meaty "main quest" as quickly as possible.In fact I would go as far as to say you could comfortably start at episode 3 if you are not already a CR fan. The episode is well paced and does a good job at setting up the right amount of intrigue. The Briarwoods, set up as the villains for the series, were the highlight of the episode, especially Silas, voiced by Mercer who in my opinion steals the whole episode with his performance. Though a couple of narrative decisions could have been executed better as I could see them being a little confusing to those without the context of the original material.I can't comment on the quality of the animation because it's just not something I really pay attention to whilst watching a show.Overall though the show was very fun to watch. The voice acting was top notch, unsurprisingly. If the show continues with the quality shown in episode 3 this will develop into a solid series that anyone who is into fantasy and adventure will enjoy.

Played dungeons and dragons online for years and this is like the game brought to life just more raunchy. Really good and cant wait for more. Kids have seen worse these days so prob 12 and up is fine.

It's quite underwhelming to be honest. Pacing was bad and the story wasn't that captivating. Hopefully things will pick up as the season progresses otherwise it'd be a waste of such a stellar voice cast.

In a time of wokeness and political correctness, this show dares to return to a time of integrated plots, character development, and story telling. Everything presented in this first story is truly integrated and doesn't feel forced which gives true immersion into the world filled with characters with interconnected backgrounds and interpersonal relationships already established. The background reveals of Percy throughout this and the political ties of multi realms is believable through the lens of both fantasy and realism as you take this walk with such a wonderful voice acting cast and deeply developed world.I can't describe the nostalgic feeling I felt, almost like a 39 year old man transported back to his teenager years rolling dice in the living room of friends, laughing at the jokes, anticipating that 20 and feeling despair at that 1. Through the ups and downs you felt it all and this is the first D&D adventure that I watched that gave me those childhood memories back in vivid clear photoesque remembrance as the character development progressed surrounded by drama, comedy, loss, and true story driven content, no matter the skin color, sexual orientation, gender, etc... This is how story telling is meant to be. Wonderfully done.

Do I like the show and will I try to keep up with it? Yes. Do I think it's incredible? No. The animation is barely passable at times, some of the humor gets a little overboard to the point it leaves me almost rolling my eyes, and the plot is generally pretty generic. On the flip side, a lot of the character interactions are nice. Not all the jokes are awful, the art direction for the most part was really fun. It felt like a more adult version of avatar or the dragon prince in terms of characters and show feeling. Also, for a show funded by a kickstarter campaign, really not bad! (Political portion ahead) I also really like how the characters that are coded to be non binary and gay were played very tastefully. I could see anyone as them, and they felt natural to the setting. It really felt good to have something like that done well and feel normal.

reviews.review_title: A good fantasy cartoon that attracts the mature audience
reviews.content: I had my doubts at the start, but the series gave me joy watching it.They bring great animation, voice acting and writing to the series.Would recommend it to anyone who would like to start a new binge.

I've seen every episode of every campaign, and Campaign 1 was always the hardest for me to connect with. This show offers perspectives body language, bringing warmth and depth to these characters! I'm so excited about the next episode!

I wasn't excepting Season 2 will be that good. Honestly, they stepped up their game in season 2. The episodes are HOT from the beginning. I can't wait for more.The transformation of characters and the backstory is just amazing. Grog is my favorite character of course.The graphics is so good. I just wished for some characters not to be in 3D (won't spoil which ones).The music is good. Could be better though.The last three episodes took me by surprise. The battles were awesome.Season 1 was just an introduction. There is more to come I am sure.Definitely not for young kids !Good job Amazon.

Bogged down by dick & fart jokes. Watched the first episode for 15 minutes and I could not get past the immature humor. 3 stars because for what it is, it's done well. I'm just not amused by the concept of D&D meets Wayne's World.

Don't get me wrong.. I love satire.. I love things like Rick and Morty aka adult cartoons... but something about this felt off. It felt like it was written by a kid who had just touched his first breast a week prior. It felt very contrived and unorthodox.It just felt like people were saying things for the sake of shock / vulgarity alone. It's just not funny. Loud isn't funny. Vulgar isn't funny. Loud/Vulgar/INTELLIGENT is what they needed. This JUST loud/vulgar with a lack of intelligence.When I watch a show I expect more depth than just shoddy one liners meant to make virgins squirm with laughter.
An excellent adaptation of the critical roll stream and a game of dungeons & dragons in generalA must watch for fans of fantasy, adult animation or roll playing games.

I'm a big fan of the table top series and was looking forward to the animated version. Sad to say this does not live up to the hype. The animation is poor, no depth or connection to any of the characters and it just seems like it's trying too hard to be an adult series with overuse of swear words and silly sex jokes. The only positives I had were the artwork and great voice acting (which was to be expected)

reviews.review_title: Near perfect animated series stunted by too much swearing
reviews.content: Like a lot of people enjoying the new wave of raunchy adult animation, I too have enjoyed shows like Big Mouth and Rick & Morty. Maybe it's just a growing pain of the show, but the dialogue is just one step too far into vulgarity and feels like the writers are trying too hard to make the show "adult". Most of the main characters can't seem to go 5 words without dropping a cringe inducing f-bomb or similar, and it cheapens what could have been an impactful moment between chracters or dumbing down a funny joke. The actors' deliveries of these lines also have this "wink" to the audience each time like "hey look I'm naughty I cussed. Look how cool I am!" Nobody talks like that and if they did in real life people would think they were idiots...All this to say the show is really well done, animation is great, but tone down the awkward swearing and save it for moments that can deliver real impact to a line of dialogue, and you'll have a masterpiece. Hoping Season 2 can deliver on the adult and not the high school/college crowd it seems to aimed at currently.
The series so far is fantastic and very true to the original series! If you are a fan of anime/dnd or anything of the like you should certainly give it a go!

reviews.review_title: Brings Modern Fling to Fantasy of Old
reviews.content: Such an amazing series making its rounds in our sphere and the title says it all. The pacing kicks in after your character introductions but doesn't shy away from telling previous tidbits of story with the confidence that you can follow along - no one likes hand holding and they are experts at giving you what you NEED to know and fluffing the rest. The story itself is a familiar brand of fantasy that brings back the joy of nerding out with your friends over a game of D&D! I cannot recommend this any higher for fans of the genre! 10/10.

I loved the show, it was hilarious, and it was great right from the beginning. I can't wait for Season 2! It made me wanna go watch all the other content this team has put out (I think they go by Critical Role). My friend told me he's been watching them on Twitch for years and he was so excited for this.

An incredibly well done series. The drawings are from Spectacular Spider-Man, by Phil Bourassa, who has signed in productions such as Batman Hush and Young Justice, very successful. The voice cast consists of Matthew Mercer, Taliesin Jaffe, Ashley Johnson, Liam O'Brien, Marisha Rey, Sam Riegel, Travis Willingham and Laura Bailey, which is already the main campaign cast of Critical Role. If we talk about the game version, it started on March 12, 2015 and lasted for 2 years, starting with the Pathfinder system and continuing with the Dungeons and Dragons 5E system (he even contributed greatly to the popularization of the DnD 5E system with this campaign), written by Matthew Mercer in the world Exandria. A passing story. The story is that a group of mercenaries named Vox Machina find themselves in the middle of big issues while initially looking for a job where they can only get money and beer the easy way, and this is how things develop. Their music is a masterpiece, carefully studied. It is a production that even those who do not know the game side can watch comfortably, it is truly a masterpiece, you should definitely watch it.

reviews.review_title: OH MY GOD WE SAID THE F WORD!!!!!! SO FUNNY XDDD!!!!!
reviews.content: Jesus christ, are the standards really this low? I'm genuinely blown away that anybody can watch this and come out thinking "wow, that was one of the greatest pieces of media i've ever seen." I'm not some prude with a stick up my ass about what is "offensive" like some of the reviews are strawmanning the detractors out to be, because the only thing I get offended by is bad writing. Pure shock value with no substance. The most uninteresting and bland fantasy setting I've ever seen. Even the animation is low-tier on the "anime-inspired" end of the spectrum. Plot and characters lacking any and all depth to them, clearly put on the backburner in order to focus more on how many times they could shoehorn swearing in the script. Really earning that 9.2/10 average, guys. The only reason I can think to why it gets that is because of the pre-existing fanbase to this.This is the opposite of adult animation. This is animation purely for 13 year olds or people with the mental capacity of one. Shows The Legend of Vox Machina actively degrade the medium. Redirect your attention to Arcane, or Invincible, or Primal, or The Midnight Gospel, or Smiling Friends, or Tear Along the Dotted Line. Please.

reviews.review_title: This was the greatest story I've ever witnessed. 10/10
reviews.content: The music, the dialogue, the comedy, the ACTIONOh my god this show had everything. I never expected to love animation so much. These actors are amazing, and this is a MUST WATCH. On Episode 3 I was hooked. This is quality content that has been missing from modern television. The creators are genius. This show must go down in history as revolutionary. A group of nerdy a** voice actors rolling dice and telling stories.Not a show for kids with the language and some sexual themes, but the plot is incredible for everyone.

Long time ago i started watching anime with the simpson, then Pokemon. After a long break, i came back with OPM, then Demon Slayers, and a few others. They all have their originality, personality. But let me tell you that The legend of Vox Machina is refreshing. So different of what we are use to see. The show grow in me. Very good. A lot of humor, a little bit of swearing. You can see a little bit of character development in good measure. Only thing i wish i would have seen before the end of second season, it's how the hell did they meet each other. We learn a little bit of each others, but not how they came to be a group. We probably learn that in a season or 2. Any how, great show! Watch it!

reviews.review_title: Amazing adaptation that's also fun for newcomers
reviews.content: Clean animation and a great soundtrack really add to the colorful cast of characters that so many people have come to love. There's a nice balance between humor and drama as well. The set pieces also hold many details that are interesting enough to make you want to rewatch scenes for the foreshadowing and just to enjoy the art itself. All in all, I'm very happy with this series and I hope they continue to not tone down anything in the future.

reviews.review_title: Has a huge amount of promise.
reviews.content: Review from someone who hasn't watched any other 'critical role' content:It's a fun lighthearted show, that has some adult humor, good banter and many a middle finger. Which overall suffers from lack of stakes, very trope heavy writing and some pacing issues.I don't write reviews; but I hate this show for how much potential it had. I wish it was just simply bad.The animation is gorgeous (I can't overstate this), the voice acting is world class, and same with the editing and direction.The place in which this show originated from (a specific dnd game a group played?) hurts it at every stage of its story.The cast is too large with the thickest of plot armor. The settings and tropes are tired and toothless, all of which have been done better countless times before. No matter how grand the visual or build up of suspense, it falls flat when there is no stakes. The themes within are also soft; the cliché of characters growing a moral conviction moments before ending the main villains life had me turning off the last episode early.It generally sucks to see a show that has had so much love and time poured into it fall completely on its face because of poor writing. Plot holes and inconsistencies that could be fixed in an short afternoon of rewrites; I will never understand how shows such as these come out with such fundamental mistakes.I see they are going to make a season two. I hope they don't pull their punches with the jokes and themes next time.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic och nice made! Great actors and the start of a thrilling story!
reviews.content: Nice anime that looks extraordinary! The characters are great and I cannot wait to follow this story and the adventure that lies ahead these different characters in vox machina!
Current and fun. Really entertaining to see. Just seen 3 Chapters but it is promising. I started without expectations but it has a great developing. Good choice made by amazon.

If you are unfamiliar with Critical Role and their adventures, then move along.It is rude, crude, and gorrie. Filled with obscene language and gutter filth humor.It is not a "cartoon" to share with your family.That said, it is a perfect Vox Machina show.I am not an avid watcher of the feed, but our DnD group is and as such I have heard most of the story lines. The cartoon has all the the hallmarks of good friends playing DnD. If this isn't your cuppa, try tugging on the beads.......

reviews.review_title: The BEST representation of D&D/Action Fantasy ever
reviews.content: I'm loving this show. It's gritty, filthy, action packed and funny. I hope this show never ends. The tone is spot on. I'm so glad that Critical Role stuck to their vision and found a home for this excellent show that doesn't compromise their vision. More Vox Machina!

reviews.review_title: Trying to hard to be "adult" or edgy
reviews.content: I've watched most of the campaigns on youtube and enjoy their storytelling and some of their voice acting, but this ruined what could've been a great animated version.I'm probably a minority here, but there's just too much random nudity and sex scenes that it breaks away from the immersion and seems more of an attention grab for the viewers or.just plain shock value. Adult animation doesn't just equal sex and fan service is cheap.Also everything seems rushed as if they're on a deadline to fit as much of the campaign in one season as possible.

I'm not a D&D or Critical Role fan.The first season wasn't great or extraordinary, but it was promising potential. The next season started great. The first chapters did almost everything right, until the event about Grog. Then, everything collapsed hopelessly. Lazy and cliche writing, predictable scripts, clueless action, Deus ex's everywhere... They were like "let's just start it and fill the gaps on the road." but couldn't do that either.Now, when I look back at it whole, I can't help but think that the only thing that keep the series from being another children's fantasy show is the stupid 'duck' jokes which are not even funny anymore.Hopefully they will think before typing another series of mess but honestly, I wouldn't count on it.

reviews.review_title: action is filled with the thickest plot armor
I hope this isn't a one season series!
reviews.content: I became a critter at the start of campaign two, so I haven't seen all of campaign one, but let me say how amazing it is to see all the little nuances that were put into this that reference many other sessions from the other campaigns. You don't have to know all about D&D to love this series, but it's really neat the way they worked in subtle game references from the gaming table and random d20's to tusk love. Love this and hope that there is more coming after!

reviews.review_title: This critter is happy! I laughed, I cried...!
reviews.content: I became a critter because of my husband and now my whole family plays D&D together. We loved watching this so much together. It's pretty much what I expected and the cast are so talented!

reviews.review_title: Solid, if you did not watch the campaign.
reviews.content: I am relatively new to Critical Role and have not watched their first campaign (which is what this show is based on). It is fast paced, maybe a little too fast. If you are not already familiar with the characters, it may be hard to keep up. Even more so if you are not familiar with TTRPGs like D&D or Pathfinder.It is still a fun experience, and worth the watch. Be advised, there is adult language and sexual situations involved, so this is NOT A SHOW FOR CHILDREN!

If you love the webseries, you will love it. All the characters shine through in their best ways. Grog and scanlan continue to provide the laughter we need. Pike and keyleth provide the goodness and innocence we need. Vex and vax continue to be the most badass twins we know. And No Mercy Percy, is my favorite character of all the campaigns.

reviews.review_title: A satisfying throwback for a Critter
reviews.content: I have been bingeing their Youtube DND series for a while and I am honestly glad that my second favorite arc of the series finally got animated with amazing animation and scriptwriting. The plot is overall dark, yet there are characters that lighten the mood without feeling awkward at all. I also felt immersed especially by its climax where I just totally speechless with everything that was going on by that part. Of course, the voice actors are also great at bringing into life the characters they play during their tabletop sessions.Looking forward for a next season, but in it, I do hope that the development of other characters would be greatly emphasized as I feel like the others have a long way to go in terms of growth which were not concluded in the first season. But even though, I am absolutely loving it!
Good writing, fast paced, interesting characters. I'd give it an 8/10 if the Scanlan character would die off. He's a completely forced character. But since he's alive...7/10.

Awesome season 1 debut. While some of the humor felt a little too modern (and raunchy) for this fantasy/medieval world, the story and character development was gripping enough to keep me excited for what more they have to offer. The action scenes were fairly well done and engaging, and I appreciate the R-rated violence. As with all these series, what I enjoyed the most was being able to spend time with these characters, learning how they adapt and develop deeper bonds, and discovering more about each individuals unique background and power set. Looking forward to season 2!7/10
...
Season 2 takes everything that was great about season 1 and adds even more to it! More humor, and especially, more heart. The found family of Vox Machina is just so much fun to watch. The will they-wont they romances are thrilling. I can't wait to continue watching this show. Upgrading my 7/10 rating from season 1 to 9/10 for this show.

reviews.review_title: A great visualization from the game!
reviews.content: I see a lot of reviews where people say "the script is horrible" or "falls flat", but what these people dont understand is that "the script" is not a traditional style script. This show is based off and actual game of D&D that friends played, that people loved, and ultimately thought fitting enough to donate their hard earned money for.This wasn't some huge Hollywood backed and written show, but instead a labor of passion from the actors who actually built a story with nothing more than some dice, some improvisation, and the imagination. And with that simple basis built a story over years that brought joy and amusement to thousands of fans.This show has some amazing voice actors, good animation, and adult situations. Some viewers may not care for the adult humor mixed with basic childish humor sprinkled in, but this is only the first 3 episodes of a very long character development story.With only 30 minutes per episode, people need to remember that only so much can be crammed into that time frame without seeming lost or unstructured.This first glimpse into what any of the true fans know of as a amazing story, is just the beginning of what turns out to be an amazing adventure. Given time, this will make new fans, and be an amazing visualization of a story that has already amassed a giant fan base.

reviews.review_title: A nightmare story that just doesn't make sense
reviews.content: This story is all over the place, with weak backgrounds and unnecessary tangents. It's as though they've tried to do something like castlevania, however, the writers are 14 years old. I gave it 5* as I enjoyed the style of animation, if it wasn't for this it would be 3* for me, and people who give it 10* are deluded.

It's pretty much perfect execution for fantasy/comedy D&D. The story, voice acting, animation/visuals are all amazing.Every show like this has to strike a balance between being familiar and being unique and Vox Machine nails it. I loved D&D growing up so it's especially good for me but I think it would be entertaining for anyone who likes the genre.From epic battle scenes that pull you forward in your seat to comedy that makes you laugh loudly - it's a great fun adventure.It's just as good as Arcane or Avatar the Last Air Bender, (in a different way of course.)The only thing I would add to prospective viewers is to be aware that it is 100% ***not*** a kids show. Lots of adult language and situations. It's all a good fit for the show itself, but be aware that it's there.

I loved every second of this series, I followed the campaign when they played it and the series lived up to and surpassed my expectations. The writing, jokes, and not shying away from the dark humor was perfect. Scanlan and Grog are top tier comic relief and Percy's dark past make the first season unforgettable.

Fan of Forgotten Realms since I was a kid and remember the heroic/lunatic attempt to attack a non-metallic dragon to earn XP....that usually didn't go well...😉🤣🤣
Excellent and fun to watch this series!!

Watch it! Already watched it twice in 24 hours. It has everything you could want and hope for in a D&D show. So happy is finally here. So many Easter eggs in the show too. I hope it gets renewed and we get a campaign 2.

reviews.review_title: I really tried to like this...
reviews.content: I really wanted to like this... and power through end the first season.But some of these characters are so annoying and poorly produced.The druid.. Every episode, every action, every time another character ask her to do something it's this self loathing "uh, so don't know if I can do this", "oh, on no guys, I don't know". Then some music kicks up and every time it's this "BAM I DID it, Omg I did it!!" And que heroic music. If she truly is that unsure, is the story that they are the chosen ones to save kingdoms and the world even believable?The brooding brother... once again. Every time, every conversation. Same with Persey.The Gnomes are well written, then Barbarian (except having the scream, "time to rage", every time he rages. I mean it's not an airport you do not have to announce everything.Throw in the rip offs (not homage) to LoTR, Last air bender, and every other fantasy movie made... it's like a lack of its own creativity. And the characters are not a strong collective on their own to over look the bad writing.I wanted to like this. But half way through the second season and I just could not get through all the flaws, poor writing, annoying characters, and constant virtue signaling...

Season two cuts so many corners. They split up the group in order to cover more story in a shorter amount of time And absolutely botched the Fey Wild arc.Grogs confrontation with his uncle is one of the highlights of campaign one, where Travis has a few improvised speeches that are actually incredibly but it doesn't seem like we will be getting any of that.It's mind boggling how you can take such rich source material and absolutely strip it of all soul and personality to fit into formulaic twenty four minute episodes that just want to move through the story as soon as possible to get to the next season.When they said they were making changes to the story I wasn't expecting it to just be cutting everything that made the story special. Seems like financial gain has the highest priority rather than telling their story right.3D animation(dragons and beasts) bad as usual but not as horrible as season 1.

How fantasy needs to be done. Great animation, and clever writing with respect to original streaming show. You can see the care and craft, because this was built buy fans of animation and fantasty storytelling for fans of animation and fantasy storytelling.

reviews.review_title: Good Story, Excessive Swearing and Sex
reviews.content: Would be a great series except for the swearing and sex. They are totally unnecessary and don't contribute to the comedy or story. If anything, they detract from a good story and likable characters. I don't know why people feel that swearing and sex and necessary to make entertainment "good."

reviews.review_title: A fantastic show, artstyle, story and character development is on point
reviews.content:
This show is proof that Amazon can give us a great fantasy story, when they focus on the journey of the characters, and not political agendas and current social trends.The Story 10/10
The Characters 10/10
Character Development 10/10Only negative it the waiting until the next season. That said, each of the first to seasons manage to keep a good pace, and does not feel too slow or rushed.This show manages to target adult viewers, while still keeping some of the silliness this artstyle allows. They manage to make each character unique and contribute in their own way.Can't wait until I once more get to dive in to another adventure with Vox Machina.

I have listened/watched some of the Critical Role/ Vox Machina DnD you tube shows and really enjoyed them.Seeing the stories come to life with the voice actors voicing their characters was a real treat. The stories have been wonderful I only wish the seasons were longer.Fans of DnD and Fantasy will really love this series.I had hoped for a live action series but as it turns out the Animation was even better than I could have hoped for.Being Animated made the use of magic much simpler with no CGI work needed.The Animation is beautiful the use of colors bright and dark is done really well.

Don't miss this outstanding animated series. The cast of Critical Roll have captured their magic once again by bringing the prequel story of the season 1 characters to life. However you don't need to see critical roll to enjoy this amazing animated series.

Starts a bit slow in ep. 1 and then turns into a torrent of awesomeness. Great story and of course excellent voice acting by the CR team. Well done folks, truly. I look forward to more from the world of Exandria. The animation team did a wonderful job bringing the vox machina team to life. Also, Scanlan is impossible to get enough of. The twins were great too. Lastly, anyone who says there is too much cursing doesn't deserve the excellent filth and vulgarity that streams through every character like a sweet wine. Okay, it might be a bit too sweet at times but I drank it anyway and you can't stop me.

reviews.review_title: Not a show that I call overrated.
reviews.content: I may not be a fan of role-playing games like Dungeons & Dragons, but after watching seasons one and two of The Legend of Vox Machina, I must express the main points that I found were under par!The first thing to note has to be the pacing! Some scenes could have been more timely in places like the lore, which prevented me from learning about the deeper meaning behind the characters and their world. If I had changed the show's structure to meet the viewers' expectations, I would've made each episode forty minutes long.Secondly is the gang, Vox Machina themselves, who never interested me whatsoever. Although they're a bunch of misfits whose job is to save the realm of Exandria from powerful evil forces, none of them, I believed, packed a punch.Furthermore, the main cast portraying each of the members of Vox Machina tried their hardest to make me care about them emotionally, but I could see their Achilles Heel easily. What I mean is they could've voiced their roles naturally, like they're in a real life conversation!I had to skip through some of the main characters' dialogue simply because I found them boring. The secondary characters' roles tend to help out Vox Machina in different situations, whoever they stumble upon during their travels.Thirdly has to be the writing! Honestly, I found it not engaging as I hoped it would! To put it this way, the characters' different styles of humour, whether Vox Machina or the supporting ones, didn't make me laugh or cry at all! The writers could've done more effort at adding raw emotion, rather than putting in stale dialogue for me to listen to in some episodes.The amount of swearing done by the characters would've been a good idea for the creators to enjoy doing while recording their lines in the studio, but not for me! I understand that swearing is the norm on adult-friendly TV shows, but it would've been better if there weren't any on this show I'm reviewing.Finally, the battles between Vox Machina and the evil forces at play didn't suit my style! The animation may have been smooth nonetheless, but I've seen better!Overall, The Legend of Vox Machina isn't the legendary show I thought it was.

The series opens without a long exposition, but immediately with an interesting subplot. With the help of which it is clear how the characters live in this world and what problems they face. We are very quickly introduced to the bright main characters. Since one of the characters is a cheerful and vulgar bard, there will be a lot of humor, music and songs. But first impressions can be deceiving. Real characters begin to reveal themselves through events that put pressure on the characters. Funny scenes where the protagonists find themselves in an awkward position, as well as in battles that are superbly staged and do not leave any of the team members in the shadows. Picked up a great moment for a dramatic inciting incident that forces the characters to make moral choices. What touches the soul of the viewer and brings them closer to Vox Machina.The antagonists are diverse, not stereotyped and imposing. They throw very difficult challenges to the heroes, surpass them in various aspects, which makes their conflict even more interesting. In several episodes there are detective elements, you can think about who the villain is and what his motives are. Which leads to unexpected plot twists, not even counting the twists in the battles, and they will also be. In one series, the authors managed to weaken my vigilance several times and surprise me. When this happened, I remembered that there were clues and I could have guessed before. For this, special praise to the authors. Not every detective work manages to do this so skillfully.At some points, it felt like the characters were balancing on the verge of breaking the fourth wall. The feeling from the fact that this is a fantasy hero is changing to the fact that this is a group of friends from our world who got there and have fun. This is suitable for the film adaptation of a tabletop role-playing game. It is surprising why there are so few works of this type. I hope this will change and in the future we will have many adventures of Vox Machina and other interesting companies of heroes in their worlds.You are waiting for charismatic heroes and villains, plot twists, original and exciting battles, vulgar and sophisticated humor, cool music and songs. Recommended for viewing for fans of not only role-playing games, but also art in any of its manifestations.10 of 10.
The pace of the story, drama, humor, and corny humor are nothing short of genius. Great story, animation, and director work. Not a joke, this pacing should be studied in schools.Just a big fan!

reviews.review_title: I like what I see.... so far.
reviews.content: I saw the ad for this show on break at work on my phone, thought to myself "hmmm this might be worth checking out."
